dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of a 1970s avocado bath, a bathplug chain drifts from side to side in the soapy water.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Every great athlete is born with a natural talent. Arnold Palmer, Jimmy Connors, Muhammad Ali, the illustrious Brazilian Pele... A boy's hand appears holding a waterproof plastic watch. seconds tick by as bubbles begin to stream upwards.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Every sporting legend you can mention — naturally gifted from birth. Ten-year-old Eddie Edwards bursts to the surface, purple faced and gasping for air. EDDIE (VO) (CONT’D) And I was no exception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Eddie, hair still wet, carries his Gola kitbag to front door. He is a stocky kid with a determined jaw.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: A week after my tenth birthday I equalled the Cheltenham Junior Swimming League record for holding my breath underwater. He stands on tiptoes, straining for the lock.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: That meant I was ready to compete at the highest level. A woman in a nightgown appears — Eddie’s mother JANETTE. She's a large, jolly woman in a muumuu and brown tinted glasses, equal parts warmth and anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: And where d'you think you're going, young man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rome. I'm going to hold my breath in the Olympics and win a gold medal. She regards him thoughtfully, then goes and rummages in t hall closet. Among the coats and umbrellas is a pair of National Healt KNEE CALIPERS. Eddie looks at them darkly until she emerges holding out empty Jaffa Cakes biscuit tin.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Well, you’d better take this for your medals then, hadn't you. Eddie tucks the tin under his arm, relieved. “Good thinki

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And make sure you pack your hankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks along the damp pavement. It’s a neglected wor class neighborhood, all stray dogs and misspelled graffit

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: I soon found out there wasn't an Olympic event for holding your breath. He studies the time-table at a bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: And there wasn't a bus to Rome from the end of our street. (rain drizzles down) And Mum was absolutely right. He wipes a sleeve over his runny nose.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: I should have packed my hankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie toys with a consoling cup of cocoa, poring over his treasured 1972 Olympics photo album — Moments of Glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't care. I knew I was going to be a part of it someday. He studies the Kodachrome images enrapt — Jesse Owens, Ol Korbut, Mark Spitz — triumphant medal winners cheered and chaired aloft.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Alright, pet. Time for bed. She removes his cup, revealing Eddie's handiwork: five chocolate rings on the plastic tablecloth — the Olympic l

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: The first step was finding the right sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie swings a battered old cricket bat at an incoming ba and misses completely.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Something that played to my strengths. He swings again with the same result. And again. And agai long into the night.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: I knew there'd be technical difficulties, and a fair bit of soul-searching. Eddie trudges home, dragging his kitbag behind him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Every great sportsman has to confront his demons eventually. Eddie walks smack bang into a lamp post.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: But it helps if you can see them first.  4. Eddie squints through an ancient eye test machine at a ch of letters — all wildly blurred. Thick lenses are dropped in front of his eyes, snapping t letters in focus.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Mum was a big fan of my new incarnation. Eddie shows off his new spectacles — National Health jam- lenses with thick black frames.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Very smart.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Dad too, I think. Eddie’s Dad, TERRY, is a no-nonsense ruddy-faced builder. gives the glasses a wiggle.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: "My name is Michael Caine."

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: The playground was less convinced.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Oi Four-eyes!/Goggle-eyed git! A dozen kids make “goggle” faces through the threadbare cricket netting. Eddie gives them a V-sign. Resumes his stance at the wicket.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: It makes a big difference being able to see properly. He swings at the incoming ball and just like before, miss completely — taking this one right in the face.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: You get a much clearer perspective on the best way to fulfill your sporting potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie drops his broken glasses into the biscuit tin.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Like making sure you pick the right size ball for your physical type. Eddie in ill-fitting shirt and shorts, chases a bobbling rugby ball, trying to scoop it up without success until t opposing team flattens him. INT. EDDIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Another pair of broken glasses drops into the tin.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: And choosing the best terrain for your endurance capabilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A starting pistol sends Eddie and his classmates into the freezing water. They all emerge and swim off except f you know who.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Let’s just say it was a process of trial and error.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move down Eddie’s effortfully handwritten list of spor cricket, football, swimming, hurdles, boxing... All cross out except for the last one — cycling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie peddles furiously on his trusty Raleigh Chopper — picking up speed towards a home-made jumping ramp. The local kids watch as he flies into the air — so high t he clears the long line of milk crates. He lands safely with a triumphant WHOOP only to discover he hasn’t left enough room to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhhhhhhhhiiii- He SLAMS into a neighbor’s wall and FLIPS over the hedge a CRASH of glass and a sickening THUD.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: It was not what you’d call a textbook landing, but I couldn’t have been happier. The local kids wince as they find Eddie writhing amid the remains of a smashed green house.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: I was on my way. Part of the big show, admired and appreciated for who I was. Eddie is helped to his feet, badly cut and covered with broken plants.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL KID
dialogues.text: Fucking maniac!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: And then came the bombshell. Eddie lies on his bed reading Moments of Glory, like he d every night. A boy alone under his Evel Knievel poster.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (OS)
dialogues.text: Eddie! Get down here now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janette and Terry sit at the Formica table, bewildered an exasperated at this crazy son of theirs covered in scratc and cuts.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Enough’s enough. You're spending your holidays with me down at the site. It’s time you learn the plastering trade. Eddie digests this like a death sentence, knee bouncing u and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my Olympic preparations? Terry says nothing. Just picks off some debris from Eddie sweater. Eddie looks to Mum. But she has to agree with Da

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: You never know, pet, you might like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits with his bike, gazing out over the lights of Cheltenham below.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: So that was the sporting career of Eddie Edwards. Down below him is a dirty noisy building site — his futur

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Eleven different sports and nothing to show for it except twelve pairs of broken glasses. (I sat on my sixth pair in the library.) He scratches his knees absently as his defeated face slip into darkness. The crushing despair that only a 10-year-b can feel. We hold. Long enough to feel this could be the end of our story... and it probably would be except for the blaze of white light that suddenly illuminates the sky. Eddie sits up annoyed, but then increasingly intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pedals back down the hill as fast as his wobbly wheel allow. Reaches a wire fence with a big sign: "ENGLAND'S FIRST DRY SKI SLOPE —

dialogues.speaker: OPENING THIS SUMMER
dialogues.text: He dumps his bike to get a closer look: "In conjunction w the British Olympic Ski Association." His gaze drops to the corner of the sign. There it is. Th magic symbol of the Olympics — five interlocking rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie clambers over the wire fence and scrambles up the d slope, all pain forgotten as he steps into the glaring li

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Bloody ada. He is standing at the top of a HUGE floodlit ski slope. He steps out onto the plastic surface and feels the sprin bristles under his feet. He’s awe-struck, like he’s stepp out for the first time onto the moon. His battered urchin features tremble with emotion as he’s swallowed up by the heavenly glare of the floodlights...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rousing theme tune from BBC’s Ski Sunday. Out of the whiteness comes an adult SKIER zig-zagging down a slalom course towards a finish line, snow spraying in his wake. A title card reads: "12 years later." A crowd leaps to its feet, deafeningly loud.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING, (VO)
dialogues.text: .+. This is amazing! This is sensational! Edwards is carving up the Calgary hillside like a Sunday roast. RON PICKERING, the BBC’s tubby, excitable voice of skiing grabs his microphone as the skier crosses the finish line RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Oh my word! He’s only gone and done it. The crowd swarms forward as ADULT EDDIE takes off his goggles. He’s in his 20s with a tan and cool bouffant hai RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Get out the champagne because Great Britain has just taken its first ever gold in the men’s downhill. And this is the man responsible, “Fast” Eddie Edwards. The crowd lifts up Eddie with a cheer.  RON PICKERING (CONT’D) The plasterer’s son from Cheltenham — now turned alpine champion and world-class — WOMAN’S VOICE Oh for gawd's sake. Get a wiggle on. Ron Pickering looks up confused. So does the crowd. Eddie drops backwards to the ground. WOMAN'S VOICE (CONT’D) Come on. Pick a lane.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A horn HONKS and Eddie snaps to. He is in the front seat being driven along by his MOTHER. A Charles and Di air- freshener swings from the rearview mirror. In reality, Eddie is a stocky bloke in his twenties with large jaw, no tan and gingery close cropped hair. His jam spectacles are held together by a Band-Aid.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Here we go, pet. His mother turns off past a sign: "British Men's Downhill Trials."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is modest but well-heeled. Barbour jackets, cravats, Hermés headscarves. They applaud politely as a skier crosses the finish line. Over in the sponsors’ enclosure, a throng of suited businessmen pay slightly more attention to the canapés an free champagne. A title card reads: "England, September 1986."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Edwards family van noses its way between Range Rovers Jaguars to find a parking spot.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janette and Eddie share a final glance. This is his big moment, even though they’re both trying to act like it is

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Knock ‘em dead. He grabs his skis and races off to the check-in, obliviou he clips a wing mirror. She watches him go, and we see th true depth of her anxiety at having a daredevil like Eddi for a child. She takes out her wool and needles. Starts to knit. Alone the dirty cement covered van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is full of Olympic class skiers, which means a hubbub of blokey posh accents. They’re in no hurry to acknowledge Eddie as he breezes in. He covers up his discomfort by humming to himself until finally, he finds a spare coat hook at the end.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (VO)
dialogues.text: Great Britain has languished for too long on past glories - in business and in sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sponsors have gathered round a podium to hear DUSTIN TARGET’s address. He is the conscientious new broom head BOSA with immaculate green blazer and name tag to prove i

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: But just as you have entered a new era of business, so we have embarked on a new era of sports — and it’s one that requires a new kind of athlete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie shuffles forward, flapping his arms and making stra warm-up noises.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Edwards, E. Cheltenham Winter Sports Centre.  11. The STARTING OFFICIAL directs Eddie to the start gate; a glance at Eddie's shoddy equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Target surveys the crowd to make sure his theme is resonating.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: And just as the world of business looks to sporting champions for inspiration, so we in turn can now look to you — our distinguished sponsors — for ways to make our athletes more competitive.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (VO)
dialogues.text: You are not just successful competitors. You’re brand leaders — the best in your field. And you deserve the best in return. Eddie wipes the steam off his goggles and snaps them into place. They're pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Target leans forward, savoring his crowd-pleasing big fin

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, today you’re going to see just that. The KLAXON rudely cuts the applause short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie smashes down the plastic slope. He barely follows t "line," which shows his best quality is suicidal bravery. much style, plenty of guts. One by one, the sponsors turn to watch. Eddie takes the corners too fast and too tight, slamming slalom flags. He looks like he'll wipe out at any moment, amazingly he hangs on.  12. Target's face tightens at this careening blot on his landscape, flailing into the last two turns. Suddenly the flaw in Eddie’s all-out approach becomes apparent. He simply fails to make one of the turns. He flies off the course, right through the sponsors’ enclosure, and SMASHES into one of the hoardings. Silence. The drip of toppled ice buckets. The dismayed st of sponsors at the smashed billboard. "I bet he drinks Carling Black Label." Target turns to his Aide. Beckons him over. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Course Official escorts Eddie off the slope.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: See that? I was pinging down the hill like a ferret. The Official can only watch as Eddie re-assembles his glasses, wired with excitement

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forty-five seconds at the halfway line. If I'd gone any faster I'd have taken off.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Er, you did. Eddie looks up. It’s Target’s Aide and he’s holding out Eddie’s gear and kitbag.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hold a minute. I’ve still got a second run to do.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Not anymore. Eddie doesn’t understand. Until he follow’s the Aide’s glance. Locates the real reason for his expulsion - the distant hovering figure of Target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aide escorts Eddie and his skis back to his van.  13.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: This is outrageous.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: It’s very simple. We've only got 18 months to prep the squad for Calgary. You’re just too raw.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: But I’ve got run times as good as that bunch.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: It's not just about speed. It's about finesse. Polish. Boys who can fit seamlessly into the squad.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Public school boys, you mean. The Aide doesn’t try to deny it. He hands Eddie his kit b Leaves him next to his van: “Edwards & Son, Quality Finis Get plastered with us!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pneumatic drill ROARS. Eddie is up to his elbows in muc “knocking up” a big tin of plaster on a busy renovation j DAD inspects the resulting plaster like a three star chef

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Too thick.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: “Too thick”? I’ve been going like a Kenwood mixer all morning. Terry fetches the water hose, unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Quality plastering’s no different from anything else. You want to get on, you gotta put in the graft.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: “Quality plastering.” All I’m doing is mixing up mud. Terry hands Eddie the water hose.  14.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: There’s no quality plaster without quality mud. Eddie kicks dried cement off his boots.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I’m still stuck in it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: How many times I got to tell you? Do your City and Guilds and get qualified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie at work in the wet and the cold - lugging bricks, hauling cement, stirring plaster. Hating every minute eve though he never buckles. He gets his weekly pay envelope from the OFFICE GIRL and a pittance. He looks over to see his Dad getting yelled a the FOREMAN. Such is life on a building site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BRICKIES sit around at lunchtime reading the tabloids smoking roll-ups. They’re a hard-bitten lot. A couple eve swig beer. Eddie sits off to one side, munching on a banana and milk from a carton. His fingernails chipped with dried cement.

dialogues.speaker: BRICKIE
dialogues.text: That's strange. They must have cropped you out. The Brickie holds out his tabloid to Eddie. On the sports pages is a photo of Target and the British Downhill squad heading off to St. Moritz. Eddie grabs the paper to see for himself. All the athlete their Olympic blazers. The final nail in the coffin. The Brickie starts humming the BBC "Ski Sunday" theme mus and miming the slalom.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Get stuffed.  15.

dialogues.speaker: BRICKIE
dialogues.text: Hey, I wasn't the one telling everyone I was going to be on the team.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It’s not a team. It’s a squad. You don’t even know what you’re talking about. The other workmen join in the humming, drowning Eddie out even after he throws his banana skin at them. INT. EDDIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Eddie lies on his bed amid his Olympic shrine. Skiing posters, Olympic albums, photos of young Eddie accepting junior trophies, showing off his latest plaster cast; old Eddie teaching little kids how to ski. His Mother enters with some tea and Jaffa Cakes on a tray By his bedside is the newspaper story about the British Downhill Squad.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Come on, pet. It’s not the end of world.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No. It just feels like it. He rolls over onto his side, but there’s no escape. Even duvet cover has a Winter Olympic pattern — skiing, tobogganing, ski-jumping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie works away in the sunshine. Radio 1 in the backgrou He’s graduated from mixing to proper plastering now. Terry gives an approving nod then exits, past JULIE, the office girl who hands out the weekly paychecks.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hello stranger.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Alright Julie. How’s it going? She comes up to Eddie with his envelope. They regard each other for a moment, quite comfortable together.  16.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: So you're finally going for your diploma?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: City and Guilds. Level one.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What about your downhill training? He gives an airy wave of his trowel.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hanging out with a bunch of chinless wonders. Who needs it? Not him, that’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I wanted to be “polished,” I'd be a bloody doorknob, wouldn’t I. She waits. Lets him finish.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: So you're free at the weekends then? She hands Eddie his pay envelope. Makes him tug it to get it free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie inspects his smartest ‘date’ outfit in the mirror — dark shellsuit. It’s fair to say he’s not entirely at home with dressing Even when he adds the finishing touch — his one pair of unbroken glasses. INT. JULIE’S LIVING-ROOM - NIGHT Eddie sits on a floral sofa next to Julie, watching TV. W all know how these things should go... Until we notice the TV is showing Evel Knievel at Wembley Stadium. He’s getting ready to jump 13 double-decker buse and Eddie can’t keep his eyes off it.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I did a jump like that when I was a kid. Thirteen milk crates.  17. She gets up and dims the lights.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay my parents aren’t back till 11. She sits back next to him. But Eddie remains glued to Eve Knievel barrelling towards the ramp.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can sit closer if you want.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I can see alright from here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I meant to me. Oh. Eddie turns to face her. They kiss but Eddie’s gaze is drawn back to the TV — Knie shooting into the air, suspended for an eternity... The image reflected in Eddie’s glasses until — CLICK. Jul hits the remote.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it’s no use. Eddie has had an idea. And it’s an idea that won’t go away as he trowels away on a low wall besid his Dad.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Guild requirement for pea-shingle is half an inch for the base. Eddie’s brain is miles away as he intently works the ceme into some kind of strange shape.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I'm listening. Pea-shingle. Half an inch.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Then what the chuff is that?  18. The strange shape in Eddie’s plaster is revealed. A lovin sculpted ski-jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks up the steps past the BOSA insignia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the reverent hush of the archive department, a BOSA OFFICIAL deals with Eddie’s inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: BOSA OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: I hate to disappoint you but we don't have an Olympic ski-jumping squad. He gives a consoling smile, but Eddie doesn’t look remote disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Not even a small one? The Official shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BOSA OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Nope. Britain hasn’t had a ski- jumper since 1936.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh that’s terrible. He can barely contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs down the steps and launches himself off like a sk jumper. Down the street he goes, joyfully leaping off eve bench doing his best Ron Pickering impersonation.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh this is amazing, this is sensational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Andrew and Fergie’s newly happy faces are covered big dollop of mash potato. The fancy china is out for the Edwards’‘s Sunday roast.  19.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Which conversion are you talking about? The kitchen-dinette on the corner?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: That’s the one. With the pebbledash. (he stabs a Brussel sprout) Bursting with possibilities. Eddie sits at the other end of the table, knee bouncing u and down like crazy. He repeatedly rolls a pea off his fo onto a mashed potato ski slope.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Mum. Dad. I’ve got an announcement. He can barely contain his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not going to be taking my City and Guilds. I’ve made new plans. They turn and look.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Plans?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What plans? Eddie adjusts his glasses. Looks up with total conviction

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to train as a ski-jumper and go to the Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie rummages under the bed, packing up his ski gear. Janette watches aghast. Terry paces around in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: This is insane. You got your first exam in six weeks. Eddie just keeps packing.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It's not like I'm taking up ballet. It's still skiing. Only higher.  20.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: How much higher?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Twenty stories. Her face drops with horror.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give or take. He struggles to pull the zipper over his skis. No one off to help. Terry paces around in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Britain doesn’t even have a ski- jumping squad.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It does now. He finally closes the zipper with a triumphant grin. Only see he is underestimated his father’s anger.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: And how are you going to pay for all this? Because we’re not going through all that again with the bank and the bailiffs —

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You won’t have to. Florian got me a job: junior ski instructor. Eddie picks up a ski resort brochure. Shows them a photo young kids being taught how to snowplow.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Florian?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: From the Winter Centre. He’s back in Germany now. Eddie points to four ascending ski-jumps in the backgroun

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In Garmisch. He leaves his parents blanching at the four ski-jumps — small, medium, large and gigantic.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: He’s going to break his neck.  21.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I’m going to break his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie carries his gear downstairs, all ready to leave. Te follows but doesn’t help.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You can’t tell me you never had a dream when you were a kid.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Of course I did. I’m not made of stone, am I. This is news to Eddie. Great news.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Really? You never told me. He pauses at the bottom of the stairs. Turns to Terry.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «+. So what did you want to be?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: A plasterer. They look at each other, both knowing it’s hopeless. Janette waits at the front door to see him off, as always

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: You're a stubborn bugger, you know that. Ever since you were a tot. Climbed out of every crib we put you in. She gives him a ferocious hug as if somehow this will sto him going.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The only baby in the world who liked landing on his head! Terry and Janette exchange a look - helpless and hit for Eighties pop music rises up as the brochure photo dissolv to the real ski-jumps all lit up with spotlights.  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title card reads: “Garmisch, Germany. Site of the 1936 Winter Olympics.” Eddie sits up excitedly. Peers out of the van he’s hitche ride in. The music is coming from the Walkman he wears on his travels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie hurries into the floodlit landing arena, still carr his gear. The ascending row of ski-jump towers are lined above him. 15m. The 40m. The 70m and above them on its own hill, the jump. A huge iron monster. At the top, in silhouette, a JUMPER sets off down the ram Eddie moves closer as the Jumper shoots into the air, soa through the sparkling snowflakes, seemingly forever until lands and skids to a perfect stop. This is LARS MOBERG, the moustachioed superstar of the Swedish national squad. He rejoins a monastic huddle of ATHLETES and COACHES in yellow and blue jumpsuits. It is all very high-tech with video monitors and walkie- talkies. Eddie moves closer still and sees this isn’t just the national squad, it’s the Olympic squad. There it is, on all their gear like a lucky omen — the fi ring logo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An LED alarm clock glows — 5.30am — in a tiny stuffy dormitory crammed with bunk-beds. Eddie creeps out with his gear, accidentally smacking a sleeping roommate with his ski-tip.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN ROOMMATE
dialogues.text: Hosenscheisser!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Bless you.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie bypasses the baby jump and goes straight to the 15m jump, all alone except for a distant snow groomer chuggin up the hill. He slots in his skis and sets off. Here it is, the moment truth... He shoots off the ramp and PLOPS onto the slope, gliding easily to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What a doddle. He can’t believe his luck. It’s so easy. He turns to look the next jump up — the 40m.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the top of the ramp, Eddie finds this jump has two gro into which you slot your skis. He takes a breath and pushes off. This jump is significan faster. He shoots into the air, WHOOPING with delight. For one magical second he is flying, high above the twink resort below. Then reality returns and he CRASHES into the icy slope, sliding to a halt face first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of YOUNG SKIERS shuffle into line for FLORIAN from front office.

dialogues.speaker: FLORIAN
dialogues.text: Class, I want you to meet your new instructor, Mr. Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: CLASS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Eddie. Eddie gives the kids a wave, acting all cool.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Eddie. Fast Eddie. Whatever you like.

dialogues.speaker: FLORIAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Eddie’s going be teaching you the three S’s of skiing — smart, sensible, safe.  24. Eddie, we now see, has a huge bandage on his nose.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLASS
dialogues.text: Practice their snowplows down the hill under Eddie’s supervision.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Okay, folks, nice practice postures. Now let's try it for real. Penguins to the left, polar bears to the right. Eddie’s concentration drifts enviously over to the Swedes the 70m. Flying through the air. Making it look so easy.

dialogues.speaker: NASAL VOICE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Room for one more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie emerges from a cloud of steam, sporting sturdy swim trunks and his huge nose plaster. Lars and the Swedish team begrudgingly shuffle up as Eddi plonks down on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Effermidaggen! Eddie Edwards, Great Britain. The Swedes just stare. Eddie presses on, undeterred.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll get right down to business if I may. I've just started on the 40m and I’m making solid progress, but I'd really appreciate a few tips. A vicious HISS of steam reveals the forbidding Swedish Co ladling water on the rocks. Like all Swedes everywhere, g half a chance, he has no clothes on.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: You have been jumping long? Eddie looks everywhere but at the coach’s genitalia.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: About a week.  25.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: And you think you are ready to discover some advices from me? Eddie nods, sweat dotting his brow, this intensely nude m standing over him, hands on hips. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) You know who Matti Nykanen is?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: He's only the best ski-jumper in the world. The Flying Finn.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: The best and the most craziest. The Coach rocks back on his heels, arms akimbo. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) So maybe I give you something harder? It’s not exactly the phrase Eddie would choose, but okay. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) What is the maximum wideness for a jumping ski? Eddie boldly holds out his thumb and forefinger. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) And that is what exactly? Eddie can't help it. His gaze drops for a millisecond.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: ++. About four inches. The Coach SNAPS his fingers at Lars.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: The maximum wideness is 11.5 cm.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That is about four inches, isn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: Not “exactly,” no. So you tell me what is the most length of the ski?  26.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: "The most length of the ski?" (why doesn't anyone else find this funny?) Eight foot two. It’s another bold guess and it provokes another finger-sn at another naked jumper.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH JUMPER
dialogues.text: The ski has permission to be 77.5 cm taller than the height of the jumper, but with no more taller than 275 cm. Eddie hitches his trunks nervously.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, like I said, I’m just starting out.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: In Sweden, the time to be starting out is when you are five. This time he gives a double finger-snap and the whole tea leaps up. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) We have not the moments for beginners. Good day. Out he goes, his naked team obediently shuffling after hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two skis plop over a fence. Followed by Eddie, all alone except for the distant snowgrooming machine on the hillsi

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Bloody Swedes. What’d they ever do apart from invent the meatball? Eddie sets off down the 40m jump and it’s the same result another ice-gouging wipe-out. Eddie lies splayed on the ice, groaning in pain. He tries move, but it’s agony. The SOUND of the snowgrooming machine gets nearer until i crests the hill, headlights blazing, and comes to a stop right next to Eddie’s splayed form.  27. The shadowy figure of the DRIVER drops to the ground and inspects one of Eddie’s craters. All Eddie can see is a glowing red tiparillo tip.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN VOICE
dialogues.text: So you’re the mystery elf who’s been hacking up my slope every night. He walks over, dramatically backlit by his headlights, an peers down at Eddie. AMERICAN VOICE (CONT’D) It’s just you? No pick-axe? This is BRONSON PEARY, the resort’s resident snow groomer He’s commanding in a weathered sort of way with a certain hard-partying ski bum panache — and yet he’s still only a maintenance man.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: You do realize the time to start jumping is when you’re five or six.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. The Swedes already told me that. Eddie gets as far as his hands and knees, wincing in pain

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Did they also mention you've got the wrong body shape? Eddie has to check. Yes, this is the cigarillo-puffing snowgroomer telling him this.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just stating the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, state this. He flicks him a V-sign. Peary climbs back behind the whee and gives a raspy laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: And one more thing. You got the wrong skis.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, and one more thing. There’s no such thing as British ski-jumpers. They don’t exist.  28. Eddie finally snaps.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What’d you know about it anyway? Peary’s face darkens - some strange wounded flicker of reflection. He turns and climbs back behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Don’t even think about going on the 70.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You can’t stop me. I’m an employee.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Still need my permission for the 70. He steers his rusty snow machine back up the hill, spluttering into the mist. Eddie watches it go, thoroughly bemused.

dialogues.speaker: FLORIAN, (VO)
dialogues.text: You'd never guess he was part of the US Olympic Squad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie points out the window towards the slope.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Who, that guy?

dialogues.speaker: FLORIAN
dialogues.text: It’s true. Bronson Peary. He was in the ‘72 squad under Warren Sharp. Eddie’s jaw drops. No way.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: “Bronson Peary...?” How come I never heard of him?

dialogues.speaker: FLORIAN
dialogues.text: Well, they kicked him out, obviously. Just before the Games.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What for?  29.

dialogues.speaker: FLORIAN
dialogues.text: Boozing. Womanizing. Being an impossible asshole... Take your pick. Eddie doesn’t care. He’s already smitten. looks back outside at the snowgroomer struggling up the h

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No kidding. Warren Sharp, ‘72... INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Peary’s weatherbeaten profile — face up as he works underneath the snowgroomer.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Come on. All I want is a few tips. Eddie crouches down, trying to make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Florian told me how you used to jump in America.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, Florian also said he screwed Princess Stephanie of Monaco.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: He showed me a clipping with a photo.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: She's just a lookalike. He met her in Verbier on a stag night.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Of you. The 90 meter at Lake Placid — 1969, American Youth Cup finals. You clocked 118 meters! Peary slides out and climbs into his cabin.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Four years with Warren Sharp!

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Three years.  30. Eddie doesn’t care. It’s still amazing.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be fixing rust buckets, you should be coaching. “Rust bucket”? Peary’s face darkens.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: This is a PB 200 with a multiflex tiller. Grooms 81 square meters an hour. It also leaks gunk. Peary surreptitiously wipes his hand he coaxes the engine into life.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying if I had your pedigree and experience —

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Well, you don’t. He lurches out of the garage, Eddie giving chase.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I won’t get any better unless you help me!

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Then you won’t get better. He adjusts his rearview mirror, leaving Eddie in his wake full of churned up emotion he doesn't know how to deal wi He rumbles on toward the slope, heart thumping, all triggered. Not sure where it’s coming from. Then he passes the Swedish jumpers in their gleaming Olym outfits. And notices again, rather more wistfully, his oi stained hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apres-ski crowd in full swing. Beautiful people and hearty SWEDES. Eddie struggles to get to the bar after another gruelling day of wipe-outs.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH JUMPER
dialogues.text: You are still looking for pointers? (he jabs a finger to the door ) It’s that way back to England.  31. They laugh and close ranks, forcing Eddie to go farther d the bar. He consults his home-made crib sheet.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: "Glas Milch, bitte.” The BARMAID serves him a glass of milk.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: You just drink it straight? Nothing in it? It's Peary, perched in his regular corner nook, surrounde ‘essentials’: pack of Tiparillos, Bic lighter, own person schnapps bottle, American flag ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: on e si . m in training. Don't b illy. I’m in training

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: For what? The Japanese air force? Peary takes small sips, unhurried, but relentless.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good-looking young guy like you. You shouldn’t be crashing into mountains. You should be chasing the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... That’s never really been my specialty. Eddie gulps down half his milk and wipes his chin.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I wonder why. More Swedes arrive, bumping Eddie so he spills his

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oi. He gropes for a napkin, but none of them oblige.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought they were all supposed to be nice. Like Abba. drink. Peary smiles in spite of himself. A beat. The two men wed together. Eddie downs what’s left of his drink, spilling with admiration.  32.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You stuck the first 90m at Copper Peak - with no tailwind! Opening Trials, 1970. I remember reading all about it in my Winter Sports omnibus... Peary studies his newfound fan more closely even as he wi his milk moustache with his sleeve. And yes, he’s disarmi genuine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snowgroomer rumbles down main street going all of 7mp Eddie and Peary in the cabin, both quite indifferent to t irate HONKING behind them.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Viking turds. (handing his open flask to Eddie) Here. Hold this. Peary gives Eddie cryptic look. Then hits the indicator a turns off towards a large building with a yellow and blue flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the Swedes’ training HQ. Peary enters using a key f his big janitor keyring. Checks the coast is clear, then beckons Eddie inside. He goes up to the blackboard covered with diagrams and trajectories.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Look at this crap. Fucking pencil pushers. He messes up some numbers with his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is what's wrong with modern jumping. They want to turn everyone into robots. He moves off in despair, inspecting the rest of the room.  33.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s why they can never understand - jumping’s a paradox! You've got to free your mind first. He comes to a stop by a strange leather harness dangling the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What’s the jumping paradox? Peary turns and looks at Eddie: Is he serious?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Swedes forget to fill me in. Peary gives a long-suffering sigh, enjoying this more tha cares to admit.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: The foundation of any jump is the take-off. The paradox you have to master is simultaneously stretching up and leaning into your descent. He raises his palm up high to demonstrate — tilting it forward, then pushing his arm out at a downwards angle.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It feels unnatural at first because you actually take-off downwards, not upwards. It only looks like you go up because the hill falls away so quickly. But the leaning forward is how you gain wind resistance. He repeats the motion, this time making a fist.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every time you stay hunched over, you just hit the ground faster. So... He switches back to the 6” ski model, Eddie trying to kee pace with him.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you need is a quadruple action where the skis come up and the legs stretch back and the body tilts forward all while simultaneously dropping. You see? The little skier tilts and drops before Eddie’s eyes.  34.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Up, back, forward, down — all at the same time. Up, back, forward, down. Got that?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Up, back, forward, down. (he nods)

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Okay, your turn. Eddie reaches for the little skier.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not the model. You.

dialogues.speaker: THE STRANGE HARNESS
dialogues.text: Swings into view, hooked up with Eddie inside it. He jump from crouch to lift-off position and flops backwards.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too soon. Then flop forwards.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too late. Then falls to the floor with a THUMP.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dead on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie tries out his new Peary method all on his own at da

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Up, back, forward, down. Off he flies and the improvement is stunning. For the fir time he knows he can really do this. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Peary’s hungover face - the morning battlefield of shame denial as he makes his coffee.  35. He reaches for his flask to top up his cup only to realiz Eddie standing nearby. Peary covers seamlessly by extract a tiparillo and firing up his Bic.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: About last night... He laughs - alone. Eddie is strangely elated, and strange still. No pacing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I think you should know I’m going to Calgary in February.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: To watch?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: To jump. Peary blows out a smoke ring. This should be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve got a golden opportunity. Eddie leans forward, lowering his voice.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Britain doesn’t have a jumping squad. Peary leans forward, lowering his voice.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: So I don’t have to compete for a place, do I?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: They must have some minimum requirements. Distance, number of jumps... Talent. Eddie shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: BOSA hasn't updated the rules in 52 years. Eddie steps back. Waits to see how Peary deals with this bombshell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, “mate”, the smallest Olympic jump is the 70m. Even the average jumper takes four years to build up to it.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m not the average jumper.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Correct. You are well, well below average. 36. He turns away, trying to get some booze into his coffee without Eddie seeing... But Eddie insists on following hi

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I can do it. It only took me a day to do the 40.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Then go do it already.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Okay, then. I will.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I mean now. Eddie comes to a stop. This is his big chance and he it.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Seriously. The 70. I have your permission?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Be my guest. We push in on Eddie as he builds up his courage.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m not kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Neither am I. The two men - nose to nose, neither one moving.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Super. knows  37.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Terrific. Eddie turns and heads for the door. Peary swiftly empties flask into his coffee as he follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game of bluff continues at the base of the 70m tower. Eddie, now in his makeshift jumping gear, gathers up his skis.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No tips?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: You’re the expert. Peary sipping his coffee, ‘miraculously’ mellow again. Ed starts up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You not coming up?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I find the optimum view is from the bottom. Peary saunters down the slope and joins some of the less boorish Swedes, who have gathered to watch.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: He’s not actually going to jump that, is he?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Not a chance. They're not sure they understand. Peary speaks to them in Swedish. A subtitle reads: “Just a little game of Call My Bluff.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up close, Peary seems to be right. Eddie emerges onto the platform, bravado waning as he looks down the ramp — a sh drop as high as a tower block. He grips the railings, his stomach tightening, the icy wi blasting his face. Peary waves to the Swedes gathering at the base of the to  38.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t stand too close if I were you. (he points at a bald ski technician) Especially you. They look up, confused, just as Eddie goes white and stif a retch. The Swedes scramble backwards.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My mistake. False alarm. Eddie slots the skis into the grooves on the starting platform. The view from this angle is even more terrifyin

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In your own time. No rush. But Eddie stays stuck on the ramp, too scared to go forwa too proud to go back.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: The game is over now, yes? Lars has arrived behind him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Give us a push. Lars looks at him confused.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A push. It’s not hard. You just stick out both hands and - Eddie loses his balance and sends himself down the ramp. The Swedes react first, then Peary.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: What the f--- Eddie instantly accelerates to 50mph. His knees shudder l jackhammers as he thunders into the ‘tabletop’, still fro in a crouch, skis screeching in the icy grooves. He ROARS off the ramp and plummets to the slope for the shortest 70m jump in history. Bouncing along, briefly upright, before flipping over spectacularly. The Swedes can only watch in horror as Eddie goes tumblin past with a ski tip SMACKING him on the head.  39. Lars peers over the top of the ramp. Sees Eddie motionles the ice. Peary rushes over as Eddie rolls onto his back, face cove with snow: “How was that?” We push in on Peary’s stunned face.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You fucking idiot! What’s the matter with you? He’s never seen anything like it in his life. And Eddie k it. Angry shouting breaks the moment as the Swedish coach cha up, beetroot with rage.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: “Damn, damn, damn. Do you have piss in your head or what?”

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Alright. Take it easy. Everything's under control. Peary helps poor dazed Eddie off the slope. The Swedish Coach's voice gets more high-pitched as he throws Eddie’s skis after them.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: Next time, I shove them under your pistenbully.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Look forward to it. INT. GARMISCH EDDIE’S DORM ROOM - DAY Eddie lies propped up in bed like a convalescent.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN ROOMMATE
dialogues.text: Eduard? You have a visitor. Peary enters and pulls up a chair.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: How’s the human cannonball?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Couple of aches and pains. No big deal.  40. He can barely speak his jaw it’s so swollen. Peary knows better. He lifts the sleeping bag and blanket to reveal Eddie’s purple swollen knees and even more swollen ankles - covered in bags of frozen peas.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I blame the landing surface, frankly. Peary shakes his head as he inspects Eddie’s jaw, still fascinated by this maniac.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: No one jumps the 70 first time out. No one. Even Matti Nykanen took two years and he was a prodigy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: This mean you’re going to coach me properly? Peary scoffs, but not unkindly.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: You can’t get to Olympics unless you compete on the European Circuit. Who’s got the dough for that?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The only Olympic requirement is one completed jump in a European Circuit event. We can do that right here. Eddie hands him a flyer for the upcoming Garmisch Seniors Tournament. So it is.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All the judges are Circuit officials. It’s totally valid.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Strap on a colostomy bag? Pretend you’re 82?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The last jump of the day is an open event... Peary looks up to see Eddie struggling to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Where the hell are you going?  4l.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Training. To Peary’s amazement, Eddie starts to put on his ski gear

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: You idiot. You’ve got a fractured jaw.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I already thought of that. He picks up his trusty pillowcase and RIPS it. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Peary sorts out an ice pack for Eddie’s swollen face, act like his amazement is really disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: No one jumps the 70 first time out. No one. Even Matti Nykanen took two years and he was a prodigy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: This mean you’re going to coach me full-time? Peary slaps the ice-pack onto Eddie’s cheek, making his grimace.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eddie. You can’t get to Olympics unless you compete on the European Circuit. Who’s got the dough for that?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The only Olympic requirement is one completed jump in a European Circuit event. We can do that right here. Eddie indicates a poster for the Garmisch Seniors Tournam

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All the judges are Circuit officials. It’s totally valid.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Strap on a colostomy bag? Pretend you’re 82?  42.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The last jump of the day is an open event... And with that final bit of news, Eddie gets to his feet, collects his skis and heads right back out to the slope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie trudges back up the stairs for another jump. Drench in sweat, teeth gritted against the pain, pillowcase tied around his head. Peary watches, puffing on a cigarillo. Beer-drinking TEENAGERS blow wolf-whistles at Eddie, but just flicks them a V-sign and carries on — a lone but def figure under the floodlights. EXT./INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - NIGHT Peary returns to contemplate his drab workshop... And in way his life. The empty bottles, the rusty engine parts, sheer self-defeating clutter... There’s no hiding from it any longer. He picks up a tool, settles down to a long night’s work. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Peary leads Eddie in to unveil a new home-made harness dangling from the ceiling. Eddie is profoundly touched. L for words in fact. All this for him.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: But what would I know about it, eh? Eddie climbs into the harness, trying it out.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, first things first. Who's your favorite female movie star? Jane Fonda? Raquel Welch?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Honestly... Linda Gray. Peary furrows his brow: Who?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sue Ellen from Dallas.  43.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: JR's wife? Eddie nods, a little defensively. Peary YANKS the harness over Eddie’s crotch.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From here on, you're going to approach every jump as if you’re making love to Sue Ellen from Dallas. Peary uses his home-made miniature skier and ski-jump to illustrate further —

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The starting gate is your foreplay. The in-run is where you build your rhythm. The table-top is where you head for home. And the lift-off is your orgasm. Same facial expression. Same straining of the muscles. Same peaceful feeling of release — if you do it properly. Eddie's nods. Er, okay.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as with any act of lovemaking, there's only one way to tell if you've done it properly...?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You fall asleep? This doesn't get a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She falls asleep. Neither does this. Peary lets out a deafening cry of rele

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Abhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhbhhhhhh! It’s a unique primal mix of war cry and sexual ecstasy...

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, let me hear you! Crouch. Clench. RELEASE! Eddie lifts off with an exhausted little grunt.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa. Everything grinds to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The most shattering physical and emotional experience of your life, and that's the noise you make? Eddie fiddles with his harness strap.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: In England, yeah. Peary walks back over to him.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Rule number one. All the hi-tech gadgets in the world don’t mean squat if you’re not feeling it here. He thumps Eddie in the chest and lets rip.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh! He keeps going until Eddie joins in, thumping Eddie in th chest again as he gets louder and louder.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE/PEARY
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, lights snap on in the neighboring dorm rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie does squat jumps in the snow. Pins up a poster of Sue Ellen from Dallas. Watches Peary use his little home-made skier to show when not to pull up your skis.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Too soon... Too late...  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary winces as Eddie shoots off a jump.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Too soon. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Eddie sits on a sofa with two black eyes. Peary shows him video footage of Matti Nykanen in action. He is a blue-eyed boyish enigma. And insanely brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie races to the jump, full of inspiration... Peary wat and winces doubly hard.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Too late. He turns away to hide his expression only to meet the appalled stare of the Swedish Coach.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH COACH
dialogues.text: “Haven’t you got a toilet to go clean?”

dialogues.speaker: DOWN AT THE BOTTOM
dialogues.text: Eddie finds his boots and straps have finally snapped.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (to the Swedes) Any chance of borrowing some equipment?

dialogues.speaker: SWEDES
dialogues.text: Screw off English! Go take a bollock! Go play with your wanker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of spindly, spry OLD PEOPLE. Eddie registers for t Seniors Tournament, his face swollen and purple.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNING-IN OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: For sure, he is okay for this?  46.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: (indignantly) He’s the national squad captain. It’s a modest easygoing crowd. Lots of geriatric laughter missing teeth. And the odd recovering Jumper in a wheelch and plaster cast. Eddie tries to hide his nerves as Peary preps him at the of the tower.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember. You’re only one jump away from the Olympics. Eddie puts on his battered old helmet. He’s customized th chin strap with a big piece of sponge.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just stay focused and do what we've done in training only better. He slides Eddie’s chin strap into place.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A lot better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antique jumpers bound up the stairs past Eddie as he psyc himself up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You're only one jump away... You’re only one jump away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary takes his place next to the MEASURING OFFICIALS, wh are uniformly short intense men, who take measuring jumps very seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wind-swept platform, a bunch of OLD TIMERS laugh i up. One OLD SKIER turns to Eddie to share the joke.

dialogues.speaker: OLD JUMPER
dialogues.text: He says, “You must treat every jump as if it’s your last.” We are saying, for us, that is easy.  47. Eddie stares down the gut-churning icy ramp.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: And for me.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Edwards! A OFFICIAL points at Eddie. It’s time.

dialogues.speaker: PA ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Our next jumper is Eddie Edwards from... Great Britain. The Measuring Officials snap into position — eyes fixed on the landing area. Peary discreetly mutters a prayer fo good luck. The horn blares, the light goes green and off Eddie goes. Peary can’t help mime everything that Eddie should be doi

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Arms back. Chest down. Fanny in... And lift. Lift! Eddie does not lift. He loses his nerve and shuts his eye so he stays frozen in a crouch and SMACKS down onto the slope, a good 30 meters above the normal landing position The Measuring Officials, who never make a mistake, are completely caught out. The crowd too. That was the shorte jump they’ve ever seen. Eddie rockets past their dumbstruck faces, eyes still clo to cross the red line and technically complete his jump.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Eddie Edwards — 48 meters. The crowd still can’t believe it. Eddie opens his eyes as comes to stop. Catches Peary look of relief. And it only better. ANNOUNCER (CONT’D) That is a new British record for a competitive jump. (not quite covering the microphone) This has to be mistake. (a hasty consultation) No, that is correct — 48 meters. A new British record for a competitive 70m jump.  48. The crowd bursts out laughing. Even more so when Eddie le up and down with joy. Who is this crazy guy? The OFFICIAL PHOTOGRAPHER scurries forward to get a picture. Click!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is back teaching his class and Peary's influence ha begun to show.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Come on, you’re acting like a bunch of robots! Technique doesn’t mean squat if you don’t feel it here. He THUMPS his chest. A row of kids, crouched in the snowp position, peer up at him wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eduardo. Peary appears waving a clutch of letters and a newspaper. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - LATER Peary and Eddie hunch over a Daily Mail sent from home an find his photo — hamming it up — under “Jumping for Joy”:

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: “Plucky plasterer ‘Fast’ Eddie Edwards set a new British record in ski-jumping last week at Garmisch, Germany, jumping 48 meters on the normal hill. The previous record was set back in 1929 by Hector Moonie."

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: "Plucky plasterer.” (liking the sound of it) Peary points to an envelope in the rest of Eddie’s mail stamped with the BOSA logo. What’s that? Eddie slits it open and pulls out an embossed letter.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Dear Mr. Edwards, We are writing to inform you that in the interests of safety we have ratified a minimum distance of 61 meters to be achieved in European Circuit contests as the qualification for all future British ski-jumping contestants in Olympic competition..." Eddie has to read it again to be sure.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Minimum distance?” Peary grabs the letter and reads for himself. One figure leaps out from the page. 61 meters. 61 meters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary sits back in his regular spot, steadily sipping his through a bottle of schnapps.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: So much for your golden opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be like that. I’11l just go back and talk to them. Sort it out face to face.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: You use the same approach when you were doing downhill? He takes another sip. Lights up a tiparillo.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: This is different.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: How? Eddie shouts over the babble of incoming Swedes as he lea

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: They're dealing with the British Record Holder now! He leaves. Peary ponders his reflection in the bar mirror seems to be taking this harder than Eddie.  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seated row of BOSA officials, all in green blazers. Eddie sits opposite, perched on a single chair. Knotted t Argyle V-neck, combed hair — his dressed to impress look. Heading this row of flunkies is Dustin Target.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: Mr. Edwards, this is a pointless conversation. Our sponsors pay to be associated with hard-earned success, not some ridiculous side- show, however well intentioned. Eddie grits his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Why do I suddenly stop being ridiculous at 61 meters?

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: You won’t reach 61 meters.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have to reach anything. I’m the only one in Britain doing the event!

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: That was the distance ratified by our Health and Safety committee. Target indicates a PORKY AIDE sitting at the end. Eddie’s face: “He’s Health and Safety?” Target gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our position could not be clearer. We will not put amateurs in with the real athletes. More chairs scrape back. The meeting is adjourned.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I thought the Olympics was for amateurs...  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steaming pot of tea — untouched. Eddie sits at the kitc table with his parents.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: So the only way to qualify is to make 61m in a European competition? Eddie nods.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how much is that going to cost?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Not too much. It’s mostly entrance fees and a bit of travel —

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: But more than you can afford. Eddie doesn’t deny it. Terry picks up a Prince Charles sa shaker.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, answer me this. If this is you now — He mimes Prince Charles jumping off the teapot spout to t middle of the table.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much more are they asking you to jump? Eddie can’t lie. He ‘jumps’ the Lady Diana pepper shaker the way to the edge of the table. Janette and Terry look at this huge gap. This impossibly huge gap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie lies on his bed, flicking through well-thumbed page photos — Mary Peters, Lasse Viren, Dick Fosbury... It’s his old Olympics album, Moments of Glory. The same b he pored over as a kid. He arrives at 1960 triple gold medallist Wilma Rudolph fr Tennessee — "The Black Gazelle."  52. A strikingly fit black woman, the 20th of 22 children, bu also amazingly — “a polio sufferer who couldn't even walk until she was eight." Eddie gazes deeply at the photo of Wilma taking gold in R - “the fastest woman in the world” - and even more deeply the photo of Wilma as a young girl, standing in a pair of braces. Just like the ones in the hall closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry and Janette sit by their pewter Flickerflame gas fi in matching armchairs.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: So he’s no better off than when he left, is he?

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Like that’s going to stop him. She wants to go back to her knitting but can’t. He wants go back to his copy of Plasterer's Monthly, but can’t eit

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're just going to have to face it. He’s an obsessive. Terry grunts.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I wonder where he gets that from. He looks at her surrounded by shelves of royal china.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I wonder. She looks at him surrounded by swirly stucco walls and ornate brickwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie carries his gear to the bottom of the stairs. This time, Janette and Terry are both waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: If we can’t stop you, at least we can support you.  90 53. She holds out a check, which catches Eddie completely offguard.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: ++. You don’t have to do this.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: That’s what I said. Janette throws him a look. Turns back to Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Just come back in one piece. Eddie sees the amount on the check and reacts. It’s sizea Janette pushes the check into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: That was going to be for your first van after you got your diploma. Terry lets out a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was the other dream I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck motors down the autobahn, splashing through puddl ferrying Eddie back to Garmisch.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Eddie sits in the front seat. Headphones on, deep in thou One knee bouncing up and down. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - NIGHT Peary idly tinkers away under a solitary work lamp. Lonel bored, drunk. Eddie enters, fresh off the truck. Peary lo up and takes in Eddie’s pensive expression.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Let me guess. BOSA didn’t budge. Eddie takes in the empties and the mess, somewhat taken a at the squalor.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twinkling lights of the resort. Eddie and Peary sit a the 70m, drinking cups of ‘fortified’ coffee from Peary’s Thermos.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I think it’s a good thing, to be honest. It means now you’ve got to do it for real. Eddie sips his drink, in no mood to be consoled.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It was different for you. You were a champion. You were always good. I got kicked off every team I was on. And the one thing I thought I was good at — ruddy downhill — they wouldn’t even take me.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: They're not exactly begging you now. Eddie looks down, toying intently with his cup. Peary pul out his schnapps bottle. Adds some more to his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, I do know what it’s like to be written off. Eddie glances up. A rare glimpse of the real Peary underneath.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course, my solution was to come here and screw everything that moved... He gives a worldly laugh, but it quickly evaporates. Eddi goes back to toying with his cup.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I was in a hospital for a year when I was a kid. Dodgy knees. All the doctors told me to forget about sport and take up reading. Eddie pauses, reliving the moment.  55.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I did. First book I got was the official 1972 Olympics photo album —

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE/PEARY TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Moments of Glory. Peary knows the title all the well.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: That was the book I got written out of.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That was the book that made me realize I needed my own “moment.” That one thing I could do to prove them all wrong. Peary watches Eddie lift his hot metal cup to reveal five interlocking rings in the iced platform.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve never changed my mind since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clang of unsteady feet as Peary and Eddie descend the stairs. They get to the bottom. A pause. Peary has something to say too. He puts an arm around Eddie’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eduardo, mein freund. I'll get you your moment. Off they weave, down the slope to the lights below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music swells as we sail over a snowy mountain road.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: We've only got three contests to make your distance before the Olympic cut-off date. Seefeld, St. Moritz and Oberstdorf. Two months. Three jumps. That’s it.  56. A caravanette hatchback comes into view — the Garmisch maintenance van.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Peary does the driving. Eddie handles navigation. On a map, Peary has marked the jumps in sequence — 1, 2,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie does brutal squat thrusts and leaping star jumps.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: I was letting you push off later because it gave you more time for your alignment. No more. Peary demonstrates using a homemade model skier.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: You've got to do it quicker and stronger — with explosive plyometric force. Eddie doesn’t know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a mad salmon. Eddie leaps — just like a mad salmon.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: Good start times! You’ll gain at least a meter jumping on early morning ice. Eddie presents himself to a surprised OFFICIAL. Signs his name on a clipboard. PEARY (VO) (CONT’D) So let’s get you registered as a squad captain and claim a pole position. Eddie tries out his captain’s armband, just like the one Lars wears.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary drags Eddie along to a ski resort building.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: New equipment! Decent skis, proper boots, aerodynamic jumpsuit, streamlined helmet. This will gain you at least two meters.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: With what? We've barely got enough left for entry fees and petrol.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Who said anything about buying? Eddie looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I already tried borrowing. Peary leads Eddie past a sign for “Lost Property”.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: We're not borrowing. We’re reclaiming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary and Eddie root out various ski boots, a helmet, glo a ski suit — recoiling at the musty smell.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Size 11, right?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: All they've got is 11. He hands Eddie the boots. And six pairs of socks. Eddie assembles his final selection. Notices Peary inspec his own selection in the mirror — an alpine sports jacket with a distinctive zip-up collar. The preferred style for European jumping coaches.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? I just like the look, that’s all.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie puts on his six pairs of socks and oversized boots. He joins the circle at the captains’ meeting, proudly put on his armband. One by one, the other captains react to their new colleag and his kaleidoscope of mismatched gear. “Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE: “Contest No. 1 Seefeld.” Eddie jumps and lands. Judging by Peary’s reaction — it’s instant improvement. Ugly, but definitely longer. Peary gives Eddie the thumbs-up, resplendent in his new distinctive high-collar jacket. It’s a little shabby, but otherwise he looks just like the other coaches now.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH JUMPER
dialogues.text: Din javla idiot. Peary flicks him an Eddie-style V-sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie - an ice pack on each knee - writes a postcard home sketching a little diagram to show his progress...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. Janette hands Eddie’s postcard to Terry, sitting behi his copy of Plasterers’ Monthly. Then she moves Prince Charles a full two inches towards L Di at the edge of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie expertly plunders the free food. Peary, even more expertly, plunders the open bar. Until a voice on one of TV monitors catches his attention.... He looks up to face the moment he’s been dreading for 20 years. A silver-haired MAN on screen. The TV caption read “Warren Sharp, Former US Olympic Coach”.  59. Sharp is being welcomed aboard the ABC Sports commentary for Calgary. Peary goes quite still as he takes in Sharp’ immense patrician presence. Hurtling back into his past..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's small, but they've made it like home. Makeshift clot line. Posters of Matti Nykanen and Linda Gray on the wall Eddie shivers in his sleeping bag, swaddled in mittens an scarfs, breath misting the windows.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: “I’m going outside. I may be some time.” Not even a smile from Peary, lost in his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie peruses postcards, gulping milk. Peary discreetly unbags his new book - Sharp Words: The Coaching Wisdom of Warren Sharp. He studies the back cover photo of Sharp — the archetypal straight arrow coach. His unforgiving eyes drilling deep Peary’s conscience...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swirling snow fills the sky. Peary and Eddie two dots on wind-swept landscape.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: We have to keep working on your Telemark landing. It’s key.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It’s too complicated. The other way feels better.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’s not correct. Eddie looks at Peary, unsure where this sudden pedantry i coming from.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What happened to ugly but effective?  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caravanette WHOOSHES past, more slowly now as it head uphill...

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
