dialogues.text: You plateaued sooner than I thought. The more you push now, the worse you make it. The only way forward is better technique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie practices the Telemark landing - knees bent, one le front of the other - without skis. Again and again under Peary’s exacting, precise direction.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Christ. When did you get so fussy? Peary ignores him. Just keeps correcting and adjusting.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: How does it feel now?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Robotic. Off Peary’s glare -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE: “Contest No. 2 St. Moritz.”

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: (losing patience) Precision is what sets you free. Form and function combined. Otherwise you just snatch at your lift-off and make it worse. We travel all the way down the scoreboard to last place — “Edwards, E. — 53m.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry butters his toast with a plasterer’s precision. Loo up to see Janette move Prince Charles backwards from Lady — awhole inch. Terry’s face: What did I tell you?  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caravanette sits parked in a muddy field, rain drummi on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary sips his drink and lights another tiparillo. Eddie fidgets noisily with the model skier as he ponders his progress chart — or rather lack of progress chart. The air is thick with fatigue and mutual frustration. And odd leaking raindrop.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Attitude is altitude. You can’t move forward if your head’s not right. What is Peary talking about?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We've only got three weeks left! Peary’s well aware of the pressure. And he’s not coping s great either. He tops up his glass.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like that’s going to help.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Well, look at the raw material I got to work with. Eddie snaps. Hurls the little ski model into Peary’s glas splashing it all over Peary’s shirt.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Some coach you are. Peary leaps to his feet, banging his head on the low ceil

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: It’s ski jumping, not bungee jumping!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Since when did it have to be Swan Lake? Peary’s face tightens. Water dripping off him. Something snapped in him too.  62.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eddie. You have a self-limiting belief. Eddie can’t believe what he’s hearing.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A self-limiting belief that keeps you small. Peary peels off his wet shirt and hands it to Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Like you're so bloody special. Peary’s face: Oh really? The two of them, nose to nose on more. Very coolly, Peary picks up his drink. Pulls out the drip little ski model. Hands it to Eddie. Heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary marches across the slope - no shirt, no shoes, drin one hand, tiparillo in the other. Eddie trailing after hi

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Nice. Nice attitude. Very professional. Peary hands Eddie his glass.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Here. Hold this. He marches on to the base of the 90M jump. Points at a Ju changing into ski boots.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What size are those?

dialogues.speaker: JUMPER
dialogues.text: lls.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Close enough. He takes them and the guy’s skis and starts up the stairs Down below, the Swedes have gathered to watch.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH JUMPER
dialogues.text: What is this? Call My Bluff again?  63. Eddie feels the glare of onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Do you mind? Up at top of the ramp, Peary clips on his boots and slots his skis, tiparillo still in mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, Peary. You’ve made you’re point. Very impressive. Thank you. But Peary is only getting started. He crouches down, arms back, palms up, and sets off... He’s like a great surfer, the natural elegance undimmed by years away. He shoots off the ramp, springing upwards, taut and beaut - no helmet, no shirt - flying past Eddie and the Swedes. and flying... and flying... The Swedes watch in awe. They all know pure style when th see it. Peary’s skis slap down in the most rakish version of a Telemark landing anyone ever saw. Gliding to a halt with parallel skid and a perfect arc of spray. Awed silence. Peary removes his tiparillo and taps the as Takes back his drink from Eddie and takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I interrupted you. You were saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie lies in his sleeping bag, awake, looking like he’s slapped. Peary is still up and so drunk, he’s turned mean

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: You're uncharacteristically quiet tonight. He offers the dregs of his bottle to Eddie, so forcefully Eddie has to push it away.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I can see why they kicked you off the squad now. Peary’s eye narrow. Suddenly this is no longer fun.  64.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: If you really want to get to Olympics so bad, just go jump the 90m yourself. He clambers into his bed still with the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your BOSA letter only said the minimum distance had to be recorded at a Circuit jump. It didn’t specify what event. He hits the light switch, drifting into sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s perfect for you. You can do as badly as you like and still make the distance. Out he goes. Eddie lies awake, fuming in the dark... Knee bouncing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary stirs awake in the morning light thanks to the empt bottle hitting the floor. Finally, he notices the blindin obvious — Eddie’s bed is empty. EXT. 90m JUMP - DAY A ski-jump elevator takes Eddie up into the sunlight peep over the ridge. All the way to the top.

dialogues.speaker: THE 90M START PLATFORM
dialogues.text: is surprisingly small. There is just enough room to put o his skis and shuffle into position. Eddie moves out, bracing the wind, and takes in the view. It's like nothing he could have imagined. A vertigo-inducing ice-ramp that plunges down into infini He steps forward, dislodging some ice from the metal grat The ice chunks fall... and fall... and fall... Blood drains from Eddie’s face and a new expression fills features. One we've never seen before.  65. Total fear.

dialogues.speaker: THE ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: hisses open behind him, producing a new JUMPER. A preposterously young guy. He opens his palms at Eddie: Wh the delay? Eddie is white as a sheet. The kid has to skirt around hi He clicks on his skis and pushes off, he picks up speed a frightening pace then abruptly disappears from view. A l-o-n-g moment later he flies back into view — SLAPPING down onto the slope. A hard crunching landing. A fierce s Real ski-jumping. Eddie attempts to move into position. All he can hear is whistling wind. All he can feel is the metal structure creaking beneath him. He fumbles for the rail. A few deep breaths seem to do the trick. He regains his composure, even managing a smile at his own silliness. Then vomits spectacularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two figures pick their way through the crunchy morning sn It’s Peary and the resort JANITOR, who leads him into the men’s restroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Janitor opens the end cubicle door for Peary to step forward to see for himself. Eddie is slumped on the floor the toilet bowl. Peary considers Eddie’s ashen face. His trembling fingers gripping the rim. This was not what he was expecting at a

dialogues.speaker: STEAM RISES UP
dialogues.text: From a sink of hot water. Steadied by Peary, Eddie splashes water over his face. Slowly, he gets some color back in his cheeks. Peary goes and gets him a wodge of paper towels.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: No more shortcuts.  66. Eddie wipes his face. Looks up to face Peary’s gaze in th misted mirror and finds his coach is surprisingly empathe

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're just going to have to dig deeper, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caravanette chugs uphill across the border into Germa black clouds in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: You need to get used to skiing at 50-60mph. Peary stands at the top of a mountain road with Eddie. Nothing to see but more mountain tops in any direction.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Don’t we need a wind tunnel for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie’s grimacing face - jowls flapping. His skis have be bolted to the roof of the caravanette. Peary at the wheel, bombing downhill.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Louder. I can’t hear you!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Arrrrghhhhhhhhhh! The caravanette speeds past the sign for Germany, black clouds in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Peary and Eddie wear waterproof plastic sheets. Rain leak everywhere now. They pull up outside an old Gothic building with a sign i German and English that says “Health Spa.”

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Look at all the best jumpers. They're tall, wide and thin. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a sail. Whereas you, you're built like a linebacker... Peary gives Eddie’s broad shoulders a squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You, my husky bricklaying friend, are going on a diet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SCALE pings to 188lbs. Eddie is getting weighed. Peary can barely get his pinkie inside Eddie’s waistband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sets off on a run, wrapped in a plastic trash bag. passes OBESE PATIENTS, taking the cure. “Slow down!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie’s head pokes out the top of a sweat box. Peary wipe his steamed up glasses.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: Private Edwards, you are a thigh- chafing horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie does press-ups while an OBESE GUEST in a tracksuit offers him pointers.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (VO)
dialogues.text: Gargantuan. Obese. Disgusting. What are you?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Starving. Peary feeds raw spinach into a blender... And a raw egg.. And a whole lemon... And cayenne pepper... Eddie gulps down a glass of the green liquid wincing.  68. A tempting box of chocolate Jaffa Cakes sits on the table gift from Mum. Peary removes them from view.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Not until you qualify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie runs downhill, Peary driving alongside.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: No rest until every pound of quivering blubber is gone! Coming back up the hill, Eddie easily outruns the caravanette, forcing Peary to shout after him.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Vanished! Purged! Finito!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary prods Eddie past a sign for "Hydro-Colonics."

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Every pound you lose is a meter gained!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scale BOINGS to 175lbs. Peary gets two whole fingers inside Eddie’s waistband.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: How do you feel now?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE: “Oberstdorf Practice Jumps.” Various squads and coaches arrive to begin their preparations. The Swedes gather round their coach, but Lars’s gaze keep straying over to Eddie.  69. The new streamlined Eddie. Already hard at work on the sl Valiantly doing as Peary instructs. Not complaining once. Just like a real athlete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie gets undressed, exhausted from another long day, stomach GROWLING, tighty-whiteys slipping off his new slimline frame. Behind him, nonchalantly nude as usual, Lars strolls up holding out a shiny new pair of Atomic skis.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: You could maybe use these, I think. The skis are gleaming, unused — and bright pink.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Proper jumping skis. With lightweight tips. For better balance. Eddie waits for the punchline, but it doesn’t come.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You sure? These things cost a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: The sponsors take care of it. He thrusts the skis at Eddie, who runs a hand over their gorgeous dimensions.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: They're beautiful. Lars shrugs — the nearest he’ll ever get to an overt disp of emotion — and leaves Eddie to it. After a moment, Eddie ‘comes to’ and realizes Lars has already gone. He turns to one of the other Swedes.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Quick. How do you say "Thank you for the skis" in Swedish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars ambles nudely to the shower.  70.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Lars! Eddie chases after him, still clad only in his Y-fronts.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Det var som fan sansldés. A subtitle reads: “Bugger me till I faint.” Lars blinks in surprise, which only emboldens Eddie to squeeze Lars's shoulder more warmly.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Det. var. som. fan. sanslés.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is all ready to jump with his shiny new skis, but the JUMP MARSHALL has a clipboard full of forms to be signed first.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It’s a practice jump! You don’t paperwork for a practice jump!

dialogues.speaker: JUMP MARSHALL
dialogues.text: At Oberstdorf, we do everything to the letter.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I could have done two jumps by now. Peary drags Eddie aside before he makes things worse.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t help it. I’m bloody starving.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Take a breath. Relax. Remember: Focused not tense. A much improved WHOOSH sees Eddie shooting off the slope his shiny new pink skis. It’s not a great lift-off, but he stays aloft appreciably longer, and lands at 61 meters — the magical distance.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: And that was without a headwind!  71.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Alright, don't get cocky. Your new skis did most of the work. The Jump Marshall signals the distance on his electronic board - “61 meters.” The magical distance. Eddie erupts with joy, but he’s so weak, he falls into Peary’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do that tomorrow and you’re through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Charles CLINKS into Lady Di, so he’s right next to her. Terry exchanges a tense look with Janette. Fingers crossed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie lies wide awake. Staring at the ceiling, stomach growling like a bear. He gets up, careful not to wake Peary, and digs out the parcel of Jaffa Cakes — only to find a note attached from Peary: "I said, Not until you qualify!" It doesn’t matter. He’s felt so much self-belief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arena fills up with officials, TV crews, spectators. Competition day. Peary rubs the overnight snow between his fingers. Sizes the headwind. It’s all good. SUPERIMPOSE: “Contest No. 3 Oberstdorf.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie gets his armband with Lars and the other captains. his jumping position.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Number three: Klauser. Number two: Moberg. Number one... Edwards.  72. Wow. The prime start time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie hurries to find Peary and tell him the good news.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Peary! You better get in position. I’m first off. He pulls up short like he’s seen a ghost. Two of them in fact. It’s Target and his Aide in their bright green blaz

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: Can we take it you’ve acquired a coach?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE/PEARY
dialogues.text: Yes./No. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: It’s not a formal arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: I should hope not. That would require you to be licensed and registered. It’s Peary, isn’t it? Target flicks a glance at Peary’s ‘Lost Property’ chic.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your old exploits on the US Olympic squad are quite the talk in the press tent. Peary assumes his most nonchalant air.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: If I'd been French, they’d have made me captain.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: If you’d been British, we'd have never let you in the squad. Peary and Eddie turn to watch as Target and his Aide walk over to glad-hand — who else? — the asshole Swedish Coach

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Back home, we have a word for guys like that.  73.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We have the same word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie settles into position. Flapping his arms, doing his breathing warm-ups: “Ahhhhhhh!” He sees Peary down below giving him the OK sign. Then cat sight of Target and his Aide, which doesn’t help. He tries to shut them out — “Focused not tense.” “Linda Gray.” The light goes to green and he pushes off in his s new skis. Peary watches in gradually awakening amazement as Eddie s and hovers like never before. Graceful, controlled, no trace of panic. It’s like he’s a completely different athlete. He even pulls off a Telemar landing — arms out, knee bent — which is simply a miracle Eddie skids to a stop and flips off his goggles. He sees Peary’s face and sees his wonderment. Even better, there’ red flag from the Officials. The jump will stand.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What did I hit? Peary completely forgot to register his distance.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was the distance? Peary has no idea. Some of the Circuit crowd are doing th usual patronising reaction — cries of “woo-hoo” and taunt hand gestures. But Peary doesn’t care. That was a genuinely decent jump. Eddie though only has eyes for one thing. The distance. H turns to the scoreboard as it clicks up. “E. Edwards 57m.” He blinks at this obvious mistake. But the announcer conf it. It’s a full 4 meters short. Target turns to his Health and Safety Aide with relief. A last, the nightmare is over.  74. An OFFICIAL steers Eddie off the snow to make way for the next jumper, but Eddie pushes him away. Wait. Wait. This all wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary waits outside, while inside Eddie remonstrates with Event Officials, voices rising.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You don’t understand. This is my only chance. You have to give me another run. They will not budge. The rules are the rules.

dialogues.speaker: OBERSTDORF OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: At Oberstdorf, we do everything to the letter.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You all keep saying that! It doesn’t help! These people at BOSA. They're bastards! If it’s 61 this year, it’ll be 71 next year. Then 81. Eddie explodes, grabbing the man’s lapels, ending any cha of clemency. Peary watches all this, knowing it’s pointless, but that’ okay. In some strange, wonderful way, this mad quest is turning out better than he’d ever hoped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long drive back. Headlights moving through ghostly tr lined roads. Eddie stares out the window, jaw clenched tight. The box Jaffa Cakes in his lap — unopened. Peary looks over at Eddie, biding his time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caravanette noses to a stop right back where it all began. Except now, there’s only leaden skies and humdrum tourist waddling about.  75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary switches off the engine.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eddie, I want to tell you something. Eddie stares out the window like a zombie.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your jump yesterday... Peary has never looked more alive.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was the first time you had all your components working together — lift-off, timing, balance, trajectory. All of it, working together like second nature. Eddie can’t face any of this. He opens the door and gets Peary reaches to pull him back.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You idiot. I’m telling you it was the best jump you've ever done. But Eddie’s already gone, hurrying out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind blows across the slopes as the last Swedish flag is taken down and their Olympic HQ packed up. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Peary sits at his desk, underlining key sections of his c of Sharp Words, jotting notes in the margins, a man rebor The sound of BANGING and SLAMMING intrudes. Peary looks o to find Eddie hollering in his garage.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eddie. Cut it out. I’ve been doing some thinking. Eddie just keeps hollering like a maniac.  76.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously. Enough with the histrionics. I’ve figured out a way forward — Eddie appears in front of him, waving a Telex.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We did it. We’re through. He’s not upset. He’s celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They only recorded the bloody practice jump. He hands the telex to Peary. “E. Edwards, Great Britain, Oberstdorf 61m.”

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s official. It counts. Eddie charges out, banging the door, whooping with joy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Everything to letter!” Peary stands there, completely thrown. This is a disaster

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matti Nykanen’s inscrutable blue eyes are unpinned from the caravanette wall. Eddie rolls up his poster, unstoppa now as he does his best Ron Pickering.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh this is amazing, this is sensational. Peary arrives at the van, now with a “For Sale” sign in t front window.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eddie. What I said about your jump — I meant it. We can do this for real. Eddie hums, dances, moonwalks as he packs up his gear.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to settle for being a novelty item anymore.  77. Eddie just keeps bopping away as he packs his case.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should take another four years. Re-train you from the ground up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I’m saying I want to coach you for the next four years. So we can go and really compete. Eddie finally starts to pay attention.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What for? We're already going.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I’m saying, if you go now, they’re never going to let you back.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: So all you can prove is that you don’t mind coming last.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I don't mind! Eddie can’t believe he’s trying to ruin this great moment

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you? We just pulled off the impossible. Now we get to be a part of it.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I was a part of it. Remember? The intensity in his voice takes them both by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It doesn’t mean anything if you sell yourself short.  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus driver loads up luggage, ready for the drive back t England. Eddie and Peary stand there, regarding each othe with equal frustration.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Why can’t we just go and have fun? It’s a good question. And one Peary has already pondered.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: A year after I got bumped from the Olympic squad, I went back to Warren Sharp to apologize. I literally got on my knees and begged him to let me jump again. Even now, it still stings.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know the last words he said to me? This is the first time, we sense, Peary has said them alo

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “You'll never take jumping seriously, because you’1l never take yourself seriously.” Eddie digests the words and yes, they’re brutal.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: They going to be your last words to me, too? The driver honks his horn. It’s time to go.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eddie. I got 20 years to make good on. Either we do it right or not at all.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You're crazy! Six months ago you were driving a rust bucket. They stand there. Each hoping the other one will cave.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eddie. Don’t be a fool.  79.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Better a fool than a coward. The bus driver honks again. It really is time to go.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At least wish me luck, you stubborn bastard. They hug awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Eddie clamps on his headphones and folds his arms as the moves off. How can a victory feel more like a defeat? He can’t even bring himself to look back. Not even a fare glance at the windswept jumps. EXT. EDDIE’S STREET - DAY The street is strangely empty outside Chez Eddie, palace stucco. Just a voice yelling —

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Hurry up, it’s starting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed inside are Eddie, Terry, various NEIGHBORS, KIDS a Builders. Eddie's Mum enters with another round of tea an Jaffa Cakes as - ON TV, Eddie flaps his arms, jumping in a European contes

dialogues.speaker: UK NEWS REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: This week, local boy Eddie Edwards achieves a boyhood dream when he heads off to Canada to compete in the Winter Olympics in Calgary. “Ahhhhhhhhhhh.” Eddie practices in his homemade harness i the back garden, watched by the local Kids.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I've broken my arm, my jaw, three fingers, two ribs, and eight pairs of glasses.  80.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Even though he only finishes half the distance of normal jumpers, Edwards can look forward to competing against the likes of Finnish champion Matti Nykanen. And can even expect to be cheered on by Great Britain’s consort at the Games, Her Royal Highness Princess Anne. On TV, a Gentleman's Outfitter slips an Olympic blazer on Eddie's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: OUTFITTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Any pinching under the arms, sir? Eddie shakes his head, proudly inspecting the breast pock crest. "Calgary 1988." Five Olympic rings and a Union Jac Just like in all the official British squad photos that f the walls. Through all this, Terry and Janette exchange a look — qui humbled by Eddie’s achievement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie rechecks his airline ticket and passport for the la time. When he struggles to close his ski bag, Terry comes grips it, so Eddie can pull the zipper shut.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Wider than normal skis, aren't they.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. For the wind resistance.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Different buckles too. So you can lift your heel at the take-off. His dad is quite the expert, these days.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You sure you want to fly all that way just to see me? I mean, it’s not cheap.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: It’s already done. Call it an early summer holiday.  81.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it's not the plastering World Cup though, is it. No, it's not. But they don’t feel it has to be anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I‘ll get this. You save your strength. Terry picks up Eddie’s bag and carries it downstairs. Edd takes one last look around his shrine. His lifelong dream finally turning real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the front door, Janette waits, as always, beaming with pride.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: And where do you think you’re going, young man? She gives Eddie a ferocious hug, her eyes tearing up. He pulls a hankie out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Alright. Take it easy. You’re going to see me in a week. She dabs her eyes and blows her nose. Terry peers in from front door.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Pull yourself together, woman. We've got a farewell committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie exits his front door to find a small curious crowd gathered. The local kids, a stray dog, the Indian family opposite, a clutch of grannies, a passing milkman. Eddie walks towards Terry’s mud-splattered van past their silent inquisitive faces. A real crowd begins to ROAR, getting louder and louder.  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, we’re hurtling over the Calgary skyline towards the McMahon Stadium and the teeming spectacle of the opening ceremony. A procession of runners brings in the Olympic Torch to li the flame.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: Fifty-seven nations, 1,700 athletes, 60,000 spectators and more than two billion TV viewers around the globe — all have come together for the 15th Olympic Winter Games, where today the words will be spoken, Let the Games begin! The flame is lit and the stadium erupts in a swirling dis of synchronized flag-waving. Drummers, marching bands, polar bear mascots, singer Gord Lightfoot, sexy ice-skater Katarina Witt, the Jamaican bobsleigh team and —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoosh! A SKI-JUMPER flying through the air to reveal a packed stadium below. Olympic flags. TV commentators. Thousands of fans. This is so much bigger and NOISIER tha anything in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie waits, suited and ready to jump, his knee bouncing a jackhammer. Around him, athletes are prepped and massag by their coaches. Being on his own, Eddie makes do with humming and fidgeti

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: So here we are, kicking off the men’s 70m ski-jump with the legendary Matti Nykanen. Eddie leaps up at the mere mention of his idol’s name.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The 70m crowd has really come alive at the sight of the Flying Finn. Not what you'd call an accessible figure. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Prefers to let his jumping do the talking — and my word, here's his first speech! Eddie watches the TV monitor: Nykanen soaring for an eter — a near perfect jump. RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Oh, that’s big. That’s very big. It's got to be at least 89 meters. Nykanen's brilliance silences the other jumpers getting ready, even the Swedes. They quickly turn to stretching, checking their buckles. All except Eddie, who is rapt by the sight of Nykanen as strides off — eerily boyish in close-up, and also eerily unmoved by the crowd’s rapture.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Edwards! A super intense OFFICIAL executes the now familiar pointi routine to Eddie and then to the sky. You. Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie bounds up to the platform determined to enjoy every second. This is his moment, right? He gets to the rail and looks down on the biggest ski cro he's ever seen. 70,000 people and his parents, all waitin for him.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: Here he comes, Eddie Edwards. His arrival in Calgary has already caused quite a stir, I can tell you. That homespun, idiosyncratic jumping style has even inspired a nickname — Fans wave a placard: “Canada welcomes Eddie ‘the Eagle’ Edwards.” RON PICKERING (CONT’D) “Eddie the Eagle.” Well, if ever there was a moment to prove he’s not an endangered species, this is it. Eddie waves to the crowd, hiding his nerves by hamming it  84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the world, people watch their TVs curiously — Eddi neighbors, Florian, his old pupils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the stands, people watch curiously too — fans, commentators, some of the British squad. Target turns with a withering look to his porky Health an Safety Aide.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: “He'll never make 61m.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The klaxon sounds and Eddie sets off down the slope, pick up speed. He flies into the air and flaps his arms with a mighty cr But it's more of a squawk as he SHOOTS into the air and plummets to the slope. He lands awkwardly and skids to a halt only when he THUMP sideways into the end billboard. It's all over in five seconds and the silence is deafenin The crowd, the commentators, the other athletes — all sta in disbelief. Until one by one they start cracking up. “What the f£*** that?” Americans, Canadians, Brits — all cracking up with amused disbelief. And the Swedish team, as always — totally impassive. They turn towards Lars: “You gave that guy skis?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie lifts his goggles and automatically turns to get Peary's reaction. But of course he's not there. The score flicks up on the big screen: 55 meters. The cro applauds good-humoredly, but it's lame and Eddie knows it TARGET’S AIDE Well, it could have been worse.  85. Target’s not so sure as he watches Eddie hide his disappointment by clowning it up for the crowd. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - NIGHT A stream of smoke. Peary watches the TV replays of Eddie his forced bonhomie. Peary looks sad but resigned. He turns back to his new reading material, Sharp Words: T Coaching Wisdom of Warren Sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie clatters back to the quiet of the changing-room, st on a high. He goes straight to his kitbag to find his celebratory chocolate. A box of Jaffa Cakes all ready to go. But something’s off and he knows it. He catches sight of himself in the mirror. Away from the crowd, he can’t hide it anymore. It should feel great and doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie wanders along, fighting a growing sense of anticlim He squints at his map, totally lost amid the geometric athletes’ quarters. He passes the Jamaican bobsleigh team, decked out in gree and yellow latex suits. They watch him go by very strange Once Eddie's out of sight, we see why. The Jamaicans pull a huge joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie finally locates his block, where a perky PR WOMAN i waiting to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: PR WOMAN
dialogues.text: A-ha, the elusive Mr. Edwards, where the hell have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PR WOMAN leads Eddie down a backstage hallway towards growing hubbub of expectation.  86.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Blimey, who else is doing the press conference?

dialogues.speaker: PR WOMAN
dialogues.text: No one. It's just you. Eddie notices a TV screen showing footage of him reading Sun at the top of a jump... doing his funny arm-flapping up exercises. She beckons him into the room and a sea of flashbulbs explode. "Eddie!" "Eddie!""Over here! This way!" More than 130 photographers, TV cameramen and journalists crowded inside for the new star attraction. All bombardin him with questions.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: The Winter Olympics descended into French farce this week with the outbreak of Eaglemania.

dialogues.speaker: SINGING FANS ON TV
dialogues.text: "Fly like an eagle... Let your spirit carry me." Eddie signs autographs and poses for pictures. With kids, parents, even Mounties. Watching in amazement around the globe are Eddie’s neighb The builders. And the Obese Push-up Expert back at the sp

dialogues.speaker: OBESE GUEST
dialogues.text: Heilige Scheie! Eddie has a quiet dinner with his parents until flashbulb explode through the window.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: Everywhere he goes the former plasterer is provoking equal parts amusement and derision. Fans impersonate Eddie's arm-flapping. Make "four-eyes" f with their fingers. Give him an inflatable eagle.

dialogues.speaker: TV TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: He's the Elton John of ski-jumping. He gives the ordinary man in the street hope.  87.

dialogues.speaker: TV TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: If he’s anyone famous on skis — it’s Benny Hill. Eddie gets mobbed by showgirls. Gets presented with a rea eagle. Even when he’s on the toilet, a tape-recorder appe under the door.

dialogues.speaker: UK NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: A hairdresser from Bristol is claiming he was your lover for two years? Any comment? Eddie valiantly signs more autographs, buffeted by fans, surge round, spilling hot dogs and soda all over his Olympic blazer. Some of the other ATHLETES watch all this without comment Eddie thinks they’re doubtful about the crazy fans, but w sense their reservations have more to do with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and his mother head towards the Olympic Village laundromat carrying a basket of his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t care who wants your autograph. You’re not going to the closing ceremony with mustard down your front. A team of SECURITY PERSONNEL make them wait while some VI Guest passes.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is it, Katarina Witt? Eddie cranes for a better look. No, it’s —

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Bloody Nora. Actually, it’s PRINCESS ANNE on a royal walkabout. And sh walking all the way over towards him.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS ANNE
dialogues.text: I know you. You’re our ski-jumper. She shakes Eddie’s hand.  88. PRINCESS ANNE (CONT’D) You know, my son Peter’s just starting skiing at the dry slope in Cheltenham.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Get out of it. That’s where I started. (off the aide’s discreet prompt ) --. Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS ANNE
dialogues.text: Maybe you can give him some lessons?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Love to. I'll even get hima weekend discount.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS ANNE
dialogues.text: Just skiing. No jumping. Eddie beams in royal-lover heaven. As for his Mother — sh gone as stiff as a board. PRINCESS ANNE (CONT’D) Mrs. Edwards? You must be very proud. Janette can only stare, too stunned to speak, still gripp Eddie’s basket of underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newspapers in every language tell Eddie’s story. Crowds m him. Frat guys MOON him.

dialogues.speaker: TV TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: This guy isn’t embodying the spirit of the Games. He's debasing it.

dialogues.speaker: TV TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: Let’s not forget. The founder of the Olympics was Baron de Coubertin, not P.T. Barnum. The crowd and media mob is now totally out of hand as BOS officials escort Eddie into the flag-draped Olympic HQ.  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PR WOMAN is not so perky anymore. She looks anxiously across at Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: PR WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure how to put this... On the conference table is a fanned-out mass of tabloid newspapers — Eddie’s antics all in print. PR WOMAN (CONT’D) The official photo session for the British athletes is being held tomorrow. And some of them don’t think it’s such a good idea that you attend. She reluctantly pulls out a letter. PR WOMAN (CONT’D) In fact, they’ve signed a petition.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Let me guess, the downhill squad?

dialogues.speaker: PR WOMAN
dialogues.text: +. Not just them. He takes the letter and reads. There’s four pages in tota 108 names. All of telling him to go home.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (VO)
dialogues.text: You have to understand, these athletes have been preparing their whole lives to get to these Games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Target stands on the steps, addressing a cluster of repor and cameras.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: This is their chance to get the exposure and sponsorship they need to survive. Watching from way back is Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They simply want to make sure it doesn’t get hijacked by some sideshow. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Especially by someone with no desire to compete as a genuine athlete. A voice blurts out from the rear -

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I have desire! Target stops. Heads turn - curious, annoyed. But Eddie doesn’t emerge from the shadows, riding out the awkward silence until Target resumes.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: The Games are not about 15 minutes of fame. They’re about a lifetime of excellence. The crowd turns back to the steps as Eddie slinks away unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vast empty freezing cold stadium. Eddie sits way at the back, a tiny solitary dot, hunched against the icy wind, feeling like absolute shit. His only company is a snowgroomer put-putting up and down slope. A steady rhythm that seems to say, What did I tell you? What did I tell you? In Eddie's lap is his battered copy of Moments of Glory. his treasured images of triumph. Victorious athletes gett cheered and chaired aloft. Terry slides into the seat next to him. Eddie barely look from his book.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You were right. They don’t want me.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: They don’t know you. Eddie looks up at the 90M jump, towering above them in al its concrete and steel glory. And keeps looking up at it, daunted but compelled. Building up to some kind of decisi

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Those other athletes on the petition. They’re not snobs. They’re good people.  91. Terry looks up at the 90 then back to Eddie, putting two two together.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Are you thinking what I think you're thinking? Eddie takes a last look at Wilma Rudolph’s lung-busting f then back up at the towering 90.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Mum’s going to kill me. Terry considers his only son, breath misting in the vast arena, as tortured as he’s ever seen him.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You leave her to me. Eddie gets to his feet, his mind made up. He knows what h has to do. We hear the discreet hush of camera-clicking —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie has called a second press conference. This time, it all business.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m not deluded. I do know there’s plenty of athletes more deserving of publicity than me. Which is why I've decided not to do any more press interviews. Eddie adjusts his specs, like he always does before takin the plunge.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not until I’ve completed my 90m jump on Saturday. The room reacts. Half confused. Half delighted at the goo copy this potential fiasco will provide.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’d only planned to do the 70m. But as people wiser than me know, taking part in the Olympics doesn’t mean anything if you sell yourself short. I like clowning around, I admit it. But I like proving people wrong better.  92. He seeks out the German TV camera. Looks into the lens.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t come here as a novelty act and I’m not going home as one. INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Peary watches from his work bench. On his TV, Eddie gets and leaves the press conference, a clamor of questions in his wake. Peary’s expression is hard to read until he gradually bre into a small but distinctly proud smile. No one else in t bar can know or understands. But that doesn't diminish hi vindication. "We're on!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Target and his Aide watch the end of Eddie’s televised pr conference with utter disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: He must be mentally ill. How else can you explain it?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: I actually think he’s starting to make some sense. Target throws a look, appalled this disloyalty. Then reac for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: Get me Benjamin Pensotti at Eventing Safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie runs against the wind with his kitbag and skis, a m on a mission. He gets there just in time to make his prac jump. It is all very regimented with clipboard officials allocated times. But Eddie is blocked from entering. And only Eddie by the looks of it.  93. INT. EDDIE’S CALGARY BEDROOM - DAY On a TV monitor, Dr. Benjamin Pensotti of the Eventing Sa Commission explains:

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENSOTTI, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: While the winds are this high, we have decided the less experienced jumpers should not jump.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: High winds? That’s not even a stiff breeze.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENSOTTI, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: It’s nothing personal. It’s strictly a question of safety. Eddie switches channels in disgust. All he gets is a news report on the British athletes doing their photo call. And an episode of Dallas dubbed into French. And randomly, the Jamaican Bobsleigh team going down on t heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endless fluorescent-lit corridors. Eddie contemplates the contents of a vending machine — Big Turk, Coffee Crunch.. His fingers stray to the buttons to make a selection only be interrupted loudly by a ‘polite’ cough. It's Peary, fresh off the plane, still with his travel ba He looks Eddie up and down, none too impressed.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: “Eddie the fucking Eagle.” Eddie’s never heard such reassuring words. INT. EDDIE’S CALGARY BEDROOM - NIGHT Peary and Eddie get to work setting up base camp in the kitchenette — ski wax, green diet drink, harness, etc.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It can’t be like the Seniors Jump. It has to be a real jump.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be here otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 90m tower, all lit up like a fortress. Janette looks from her hotel window, trying to hide her nerves and fail badly. Terry sits at the bureau, customizing a shiny new ski hel

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Get some sleep, pet. I got it covered. He pops open a tin of varnish. Dips in a brush. INT. EDDIE’S CALGARY BEDROOM - NIGHT Eddie’s single bed lies empty, stripped of its blankets. Nearby, a fold-out bed stands unopened. Instead, Eddie and Peary lie side by side on the floor, j like in the caravanette. The wind whistles outside, flapping the curtain. Neither can sleep and they have to acknowledge it.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Have a cigarillo if you want.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: It’s just jetlag. (no it’s not) Eddie fidgets noisily. Peary reaches out to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I can’t help it. He really can’t. He rushes to the toilet. Heaves violentl into the bowl. Peary has his own nerves to deal with. His hand hovers ov the flask in his bag... Somehow he refrains. Eddie waxes his skis... Just like his Dad plastering the of a low wall.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Peary?  95.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Eduardo.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Jumping’s my Sistine Chapel and you're my brush. Eddie heaves one last time. Gets back into his sleeping b pale as a sheet. Outside the wind howls remorselessly.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You ever get the feeling you’ve made the biggest mistake of your life? His questions hangs in the air. They continue to lie ther lost in their private hopes and fears. We fade to black. We fade back up: “Six hours later.” Eddie and Peary are still staring at the ceiling, only no the first rays of dawn are peeping through the curtain. P gets to his feet and extends a finger: Listen.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it? He can’t hear anything. Which is precisely Peary’s point. Eddie scrambles to his feet and pulls back the curtains. clear blue sky. Not a flag fluttering anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They can’t use the weather as an excuse now, can they. Peary sets out Eddie’s breakfast, a glass of green sludge

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Neither can we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olympic Officials go down the hall, delivering sheets of paper at each door with a sharp KNOCK.  96.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Klauser. Start time... Puikkonen. Start time... Edwards. Start time... Eddie opens his door to collect his start time and finds parents waiting there awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: We wanted to give you this. She holds out an airport shopping bag.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Your duty free? Terry pulls out the new ski helmet now customized with th word “Eagle” on the front in gold.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a helmet.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: A safety helmet. Terry throws her a look: I’1l handle this.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I put some Styrofoam inlay panels at the key pressure points and a few extra coats of shellac polyurethane for general reinforcement. He hands the helmet to Eddie, pointing out his handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Good thinking.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: You can’t be too careful. Terry throws her another look: I said, I'll handle it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: We just wanted to wish you luck. That’s all. Eddie runs a hand over the helmet.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Top quality finish, Dad.  97. Janette can’t hide her fear any longer. She hugs Eddie so tightly he can barely breathe.

dialogues.speaker: JANETTE
dialogues.text: Oh Eddie — Terry glares furiously at his wife, betraying his own ner more than anything else.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I thought we agreed to play it cool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fans STREAM into the stadium. Finally, it’s D-Day. A row of global TV commentators — each one excitably reporting in his native tongue. Apart from the lugubrious fellow with a blonde beard. What a surprise. It’s Swedish

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: That was Bruce "Blizzard" Sassoon, the American, opening his account with a distance of 109.5 meters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Ahhhhhhhhh.” The applause of the crowd echoes from outsi as Eddie warms up, Peary massages his calfs.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I want to hear you at the back of the stands. If you’re not yelling it, you're not selling it — Waters drips on the floor. Peary is suddenly eye to eye w a couple of naked Swedes. Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: You are quite the popular fellow, Eagle-Man. Every time we turn on TV, you are there.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: Maybe, perhaps, you could tell us... What is the secret?

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Clothes. A KLAXON sounds for the next jump.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janette and Terry take their seats. Her knitted sweater s "I'm Eddie’s Mum."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary gets Eddie to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: And remember: you’re going to land so much harder on this jump. So when your skis hit the slope keep that fanny up. Whatever it takes, don’t drop back otherwise... A huge GASP goes up from the crowd. The TV MONITOR shows a jump has gone horribly wrong — a monster wipe-out on the slope. PEARY (OS) (CONT’D) Otherwise, you’re going to be joining him.

dialogues.speaker: OUT IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: Janette and Terry watch in horror as medics stretcher off injured jumper. It’s a broken limb at the least.

dialogues.speaker: CANUCK ANCHORMAN
dialogues.text: And that may not be the only wipe- out of the day. Not with Britain’s Eddie “the Eagle” Edwards coming up soon. Take a look at this. They run footage of Peary arriving with Eddie earlier. CANUCK ANCHORMAN (CONT’D) Eddie’s coach is none other than Bronson Peary, fallen whiz kid of ‘70s ski-jumping and an old Olympic squad member of yours, if I’m not mistaken, Warren?

dialogues.speaker: WARREN SHARP
dialogues.text: We had a few years together.  99. SUPERIMPOSE: “Warren Sharp, Former US Olympics Coach.” A Living Legend, no question. And not a man to waste words.

dialogues.speaker: CANUCK ANCHORMAN
dialogues.text: How do you feel about this unconventional return? Sharp flattens out his palms, not unprepared for the question.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN SHARP
dialogues.text: There’s an old expression in jumping. ‘You’re never bigger than the hill.’ That was Bronson Peary to a T. And it broke my heart. I could never reach him. He was such a natural talent when he was young. Technique, flair — everything but discipline and humility.

dialogues.speaker: CANUCK ANCHORMAN
dialogues.text: And now? Sharp ponders the question deeply. Finally —

dialogues.speaker: WARREN SHARP
dialogues.text: He disrespected the sport so totally as a jumper, I’m just sad he’s going to do the same thing today as a coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The changing-room has fallen silent. Peary turns from the monitor to find the whole room staring at him. He doesn’t even attempt to make light of it. An Official enters and points at him and Eddie. You. Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Peary are ushered down the tunnel, two silhouet heading towards the rising wall of noise. One last glance each other before they step out into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electric excitement pulses through the athletes and offic ‘backstage,’ including a British contingent.  100. One by one, they start to recognize Eddie. So this is the infamous Eagle. Peary steers Eddie through the gauntlet of stares, feelin the mounting pressure. He gets to the check-in desk. Hands over their paperwork. Mouth like cotton. They pass through to the elevator at t base of the tower. Eddie’s not sure what to do. So Peary leans over and pres the button — just like a regular elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down in the stands, Eddie’s parents feel the buzz in the crowd. Officials hurry into position. TV crews from every country get the countdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the elevator descends, Peary checks Eddie’s equipment the last time. The doors open with a hiss. It’s all happening too fast. Peary CLASPS Eddie’s arms. A complicated last look: fear, affection, resolve. A coach's complete faith in his pupil

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: You know what to do. He thumps Eddie’s chest, just like in their first lesson.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Linda Gray. All or nothing. Eddie backs onto the elevator, joined by another athlete, who’s just strolled up. As the doors HISS shut —

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See you at the bottom. But the words are too late. All Peary can do now is step backwards and tilt his head back to look up... And up... up... It is truly a concrete monster of a jump.  101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the roar of the crowd is eerily distant. Just the rhythmic hum of the winching cables ascending into the sk Eddie stares ahead, trying to keep calm. Suddenly -

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Jumping is all that matters. If I didn’t jump, I would drink and have sex all the time. Eddie turns and blinks. It is MATTI NYKANEN. His caravane poster made flesh. Blonde, boyish and surprisingly small (5ft 8in), which th Eddie even more.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN
dialogues.text: Everything else is shit, no? Eddie searches for a suitable reply.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: «+. Congratulations on your medal.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN
dialogues.text: I win gold, but it was not my best. If I had done my best, I could have come last and been happier.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What, like me? His strained laugh is quickly silenced.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN
dialogues.text: You did not do so good either.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, not so good.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN
dialogues.text: You've done better.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (a chastised schoolboy) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN
dialogues.text: You laugh. You think I am being patronizing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Eddie's not laughing at all) But you and I are like one o’clock and eleven o’clock. Nykanen extends two gloved fingers to demonstrate. A V-si over Eddie’s nose.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Closer to each other than to the others. Winning, losing — that’s for the little people. He rotates his V-sign so a finger now points at each of t

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men like us, we jump to free our souls. Eddie stares back, frankly bewildered. The doors HISS ope Nykanen doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: -+. I think this is our floor. He still doesn’t get it. Nykanen leans in and grasps Eddi lapels.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN
dialogues.text: The only two jumpers with a chance to make history today are you and I. His stare is rich with self-loathing and threat.

dialogues.speaker: NYKANEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we do less than our best with the whole world watching, it will kill us inside for all time. And with that cheery parting thought, he steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary hurries down to his viewpoint, passing under the ga of his old coach in the TV gantry box.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: Here he comes, the Flying Finn. Matti Nykanen getting into position to go for an unprecedented second gold for jumping.  103. Eddie is instructed to wait on the bench. But he can’t he peering over as Nykanen sets off, hurtling down the jump. is a nigh perfect jump: 118.5m. Alpine poetry in motion. The commentators are in raptures. The crowd applauds like crazy. Eddie is momentarily relieved — it is like a bless — until he sees the close-up of Nykanen’s face on the monitor, the tiny telling hint of disappointment. Nykanen turns his piercing blue-eyed stare into the camer right into Eddie’s soul.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Edwards!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie moves onto the start platform. And now it all becom terrifyingly real. The horizon starts to sway. The sound SCRATCHING echoes in his head. His knees go weak and his stomach heaves. It’s just like the last time he was on the 90. He spits into his steamed-up goggles, but nothing comes o The Official locks Eddie into position as he stares down monstrous ramp. No wind. No snow. No creaking metal. Just dying rumble of the crowd — the whole world — falling sil as they wait for him to fail. His pupils, his neighbors, the builders, the local kids — glued to their sets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pickering drops his voice to a whisper as we pull back - back - and back - to see the full magnitude of Eddie’s ta a 90m sheer drop, as high as a tower block.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: The jump here at Calgary is a doubly tricky one. The short tabletop gives the jumpers less time than normal to get aligned for the push off. And the slope is a steeper than average 38 degrees. A ‘high-tech’ 80s graphic illustrates the steepness.  104. RON PICKERING (CONT’D) In short, it’s the fastest, most unforgiving slope in the world, especially when it comes to landings. And if Edwards has one weakness — one salient weakness, I should say — it’s his landings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie grips the rail, inching into position as the amber light comes on.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: Okay. Here we go... But Eddie doesn’t move. At all. RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Don’t tell me he’s frozen up. Actually, it’s worse. Eddie’s shuffling back. RON PICKERING (CONT’D) It’s going to have to be a re-set. This is it for Edwards. Last and final chance. Eddie re-focuses, sweat beads on his forehead. The light turns amber and then green, burning in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Come on, you bugger, get moving. Eddie pushes off, crouching low, picking up speed. The wind pummels his cheeks as he hits 30 - 40 - 50mph. A glorious, terrifying view spreading out below him... He hurtles into the tabletop. Knees juddering over the ri ice. Going the fastest he’s ever skied in his life.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: Here goes Edwards into the straight. He’s got to pick his moment just right - Peary urges Eddie into his lift-off.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Push. Up and out. Up and out.  105. Eddie stretches for his life, straining into the wind, as skis shoot off the ramp edge.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: He’s away, but it was late. That was very late. That’s going to cause all kinds of problems. Janette and Terry hold each other tight in the crowd. Eddie’s ski-tips swing up to his face — dangerously close He’s leaning forward. Way forward. RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Oh no. He’s going to lose his balance. His pupils go wide-eyed. Janette turns away, unable to lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie grits his teeth as he reaches the pinnacle of his flight. Still no sound coming from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: How he’s going to make this landing, I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Release! But Eddie’s still not yelling anything as - He flaps his arms desperately — still no sound coming fro his mouth — as he starts to fall - Target's cold eyes burning into his brain...

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, release! Peary thumps his chest.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: He’s coming in too steeply, surely. The slope rushing upwards beneath his shuddering ski tips As Eddie sees Wilma Rudolph smash through the finish tape he finally summons up his voice and lets rip —

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Abhhhhhhhhhhhhhbhh...  106. Drowning out every rejection, every setback.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Abhhhhhhhhhhhhhhbhhh!!!

dialogues.speaker: BUILDERS /PUPILS/KIDS
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh!!!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Abhhhhhhhhhhhhhhbhhh!!! His skis SLAM into the snow, his whole body ROCKED with t impact... Just like jumping milk crates on his bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: Oh no! Janette and Terry wince. The crowd gasps. Eddie’s butt ha dropped, his arms are flailing, but he’s still screaming.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Abhhhhhhhhhhhhh! !! Target starts to smile with vindication... Some of the commentators too. But Peary refuses to concede defeat.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Up! Up! Eddie gives one final agonizing push and with all his mig lifts his body back upwards to crest the safety bump and shoot his arms into the air. It’s good. He’s safe. He’s made it.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (leaping the barrier) Ahhhhhhh, you motherf-----

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: Unbelievable! Unbelievable. Janette and Terry whoop and holler, sending their neighbo popcorn flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peary rushes to Eddie as he skis to a stop. Ahhhhhhhhhhhh It’s a two-man primal meltdown.  107.

dialogues.speaker: RON PICKERING
dialogues.text: I've been waiting nearly two weeks to say this. Well, here goes — The Eagle has Landed! The crowd ROAR and CHEER, loving every second as Peary an Eddie hug and topple over into the snow. Everyone’s letting rip. The Swedish coach EVEN gives a cu nod to Lars. Not bad. The only person conspicuously not watching this is Target RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Britain’s Eddie Edwards has completed his large hill jump — and it’s a belter. A small jump for mankind, a very small jump, but it’s a personal best in competition for Edwards — 71.5 meters. And that is a new British Record. Peary and Eddie get control of themselves until they see result flash up: “71.5m... A new UK record.” Peary turns to catch Warren Sharp’s reaction, up in the commentary box. But Sharp is already removing his headpho and leaving... Peary’s disappointment is swept aside by Eddie hugging hi all over again, falling onto the snow. RON PICKERING (CONT’D) What a sight. What an amazing sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Peary tumble into the dressing room. Eddie goes straight for the Jaffa Cakes only to notice the muted watchful glances from the other athletes... Alerting them the august presence waiting by their locker. Warren Sharp, as they live and breathe. His aura is even impressive in the flesh, almost religious in effect. His eyes meet Peary’s. The forbidding father and the outc son. A electrically charged reunion 20 years in the makin Sharp slowly reaches into Peary's bag. Eddie stiffens.... instead of a flask, Sharp pulls out Peary’s copy of Sharp Words. Notices the many comments scrawled in the margins.  108.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN SHARP
dialogues.text: Interesting read? Peary manages a nod.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: Very... He’s actually lost for words.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN SHARP
dialogues.text: Instructive? Sharp pulls out a thick Mont Blanc pen. Inscribes the tit page. The room is so quiet, everyone can hear the pen scratching. He finishes and hands Peary the book, considering his for athlete, and the man he’s become.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN SHARP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was wrong about you today. No more words are needed. The atonement is complete. He g Peary’s shoulder a paternal squeeze, pent-up emotion floo across Peary’s face. The soothing hum of a plane fades up, taking them home -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Peary in steerage, utterly drained, utterly content, enjoying it all — drinks, snacks, headphones and copy of the Calgary Herald.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: “The most raucous applause came during Olympic President Juan Antonio Samaranch’s speech at the closing ceremony when he said, “Some competitors have won gold and some have broken records, and one has even flown like an eagle...” Peary digs out his copy of Sharp Words and flips to the title page.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: I think I can match that. He shows Eddie the handwritten inscription.  109.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: “Now the real works begins - W.S.” Peary picks up his glass of bubbly.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: So how about it? To the next four years? Eddie picks up his glass of milk.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: At the least. They clink and drink, not noticing the ominous blur of gr making its way towards them from first class.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: They have hangers, you know. It's Target. He moves aside Eddie’s folded-up blazer up o the empty seat. Sits down on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: It’s only fair to tell you. A motion has already been approved to amend the entry criteria for the next Olympics. He pauses to savor the killer blow.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You will never be wearing this blazer again. He shifts closer, free at last to say what he really thin

dialogues.speaker: TARGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think because a few TV pundits find your antics amusing, you've done something to be proud of. But you came last — twice. You made fools of your countrymen. You embarrassed your flag. When you get home, you're going to find out how funny that really is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An endless terminal corridor, down which Eddie pushes his baggage cart, Peary alongside, the blazer resting on his  110. It is a desolate place. Jetlagged passengers shuffling li zombies. Except the odd one who whispers and points at Ed Up ahead at Customs, Target is surrounded by his gleaming downhill boys. All spruced up in their blazers. They poin out Eddie to some CUSTOMS OFFICIALS.

dialogues.speaker: PEARY
dialogues.text: My connection’s Terminal 3.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Time for a coffee then. Before Eddie can follow Peary, the Officers approach him.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMS OFFICER
dialogues.text: This way, sir. Eddie is taken to one side while Target and his chinless wonders are escorted through.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMS OFFICER
dialogues.text: If you just come with me, we can explain it all. Peary is told to keep moving. “Nothing to see here.” Another OFFICIAL arrives to take Eddie’s bag and skis. Le him into a sideroom — Eddie, a German Shepherd and two customs officials alone in a tiny room.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It’s not a drugs test is it? The Officers share a wry glance, which is really unnervin

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Cos I can tell you now, I’ve never taken a steroid in my life - A far door opens and a forbidding SENIOR OFFICIAL enters.

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR CUSTOMS OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: This is him is it? Righty-o. Let’s get this moving. He gestures firmly for Eddie to follow him. SENIOR CUSTOMS OFFICIAL (CONT’D) This way, sir.  111. Eddie, his nerves already at breaking point, is steered forward through the second door and his jaw hits the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand people are waiting for him. Crammed in with banners, flags, foam fingers, stetsons. There’s women in bikinis from a vodka company, TV cameras, his local Mayor His whole life before his eyes: his parents, Julie, the neighbors, the builders. All there for him. This isn’t the polite amusement of the Calgary crowd. Thi a full-on folk hero explosion. The great stonewashed. Not prettiest bunch in the world, but the most adoring.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Bloody ada. Janette gives him the proudest hug of her life, tearing u as well-wishers gather round and flashbulbs explode.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Alright, alright, calm down. Terry takes his turn to hug Eddie only to tear up even mo

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now look what you made me do.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (dabbing his own eyes now) Me? You started it. Everywhere he looks — delirious faces wearing pink Eddie- style glasses. Hanging over balconies, clambering onto ch in counters. Even some policemen are craning their necks a better look. Some of the British athletes are there too, swept along b chaotic energy of the crowd. Giving it up. One team-mate another. Eddie catches Target’s face, tight-lipped with rage, as h Aide and the downhill squad mutinously join in clapping. An equally amazed Peary joins the fold as one of the Tabl Reporters sticks a microphone under Target’s nose.  112.

dialogues.speaker: BLUFF JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Target! The one British athlete being acclaimed as a hero is the very person you didn’t want to compete. Any comment?

dialogues.speaker: TARGET
dialogues.text: Piss off. Eddie and Peary turn from this clinching irony to face ea other and the emotion is overwhelming — relief, joy, vindication... The crowd hoists Eddie onto its shoulders, lifting him in full view. The effect is like a winning goal. He can’t de whether to smile or cry. So he does both, waving and wavi For Eddie, finally, the dream has come true. He gives the for-victory sign — the reverse of what he’s been giving s he was a kid — as we freeze-frame and immortalize what ha just turned into the greatest day of his life. SUPERIMPOSE: “Eddie continued to jump in European contests and eventually retired with a personal best of 115m — a new British record.”
